He's furious that so many people throw their trash in the river and it causes streams like this. Now Ryu is punching and kicking and tatsumaki senpukyaku-ing all of the trash into burnable and non-burnable piles. But the stream doesn't end. Now he's trying to get his other Street Fighter pals to help him beat it back!

mnemonics.meaning: The radical suit and the kanji suit are exactly the same! This kanji can also mean join which makes sense. When something suits you well, like a hat or something, it joins together with you quite well too. Join me, my hat! You suit my head well. It just fits, you know? Just remember that this "suit" means "to suit you" - not the thing you wear, okay!
mnemonics.reading: You need someone who will suit you. Someone who can join you on your life journey. So you call Grandpa Koichi (ごういち). Note: For ごう reading mnemonics, we use ごういち (grandpa Koichi) because こういち is used for the こう reading. こう becomes ごう becomes "grandpa ごういち." Imagine you two standing next to each other, posing for a photograph. You two suit each other well. ごういち with his gray beard, and you with your [well, you have to fill in this part by yourself].

mnemonics.meaning: A building has easy access to sunshine. It's big and tall, so the sunlight shines right onto its roof. You're standing on top of the building as the sunshine comes down. Its warm light fills your entire body as it covers the building with ease.
mnemonics.reading: Standing in sunshine for this long has worked up your appetite, so you take a yogurt (よう) cup out of your bag and eat it. Feel the sunlight on your face and taste the yogurt on your tongue. What flavor is it? Try to imagine it as vividly as you can so that sunlight always tastes like yogurt from now on.

mnemonics.meaning: Stop! That box of rice is actually full of teeth! I know it says "rice" on the cover, but I promise you those are all teeth and if you bite into them you'll break a tooth of your own. Stop what you're doing and look into the rice box. Nope, it's definitely full of teeth. There's a grain or two of rice, but it's like 98% teeth.
mnemonics.reading: Why do I have a rice box full of teeth? Ha (は)! Wouldn't you like to know. Ha! I definitely have an answer that isn't weird or creepy. Ha... ha ha... Ha! Wouldn't you like to know why there are teeth in there? Ha. Ha ha. HA HA HA HA!

mnemonics.meaning: If someone is headed in your direction with a gun, nock an arrow in your bow and gather your tribe behind you because it’s about to get real! This cretin with a gun is headed your direction and he doesn’t even know what you and your tribe are gonna do to him. If he gets any closer, you’re likely to shoot that arrow right at him. This guy headed your direction with his gun doesn’t look friendly at all. Hear the sound of the bowstring as you nock your arrow and prepare your shot to defend yourself. Then imagine the sound of everyone in your tribe doing the same.
mnemonics.reading: When he starts to get closer, you notice that this guy is a bosozoku (ぞく) bike gang member. Bosozoku means “running tribe” and this guy is running right at you. With a gun. So gather your own tribe behind you and prepare to defend yourself against this bosozoku member. You remember what a bosozoku is, right? We wrote about them on Tofugu a while ago. They’re bike gang members and the “zoku” in bosozoku means tribe. Remember that article when you see this kanji.

mnemonics.meaning: If your friendly neighborhood tofu takes a gun and points it in your direction, you might want to take a trip. This tofu obviously has something wrong with it. If it’s taking a gun and pointing it in your direction, now’s probably a good time to get away and take that trip you’d been talking about. Imagine this menacing block of tofu threatening you with a gun. Guns are scary so you want to get away. Use images of your trip to make the thoughts of the big bad tofu and his gun fade away.
mnemonics.reading: Your plan didn't work and the tofu went on your trip with you. And now it's wearing your hotel robe (りょ)! It looks so comfortable, wrapped up in the robe. That's the best part of going on trips, and he stole it from you. Imagine being stuck on a trip with a block of tofu that took your robe and is wearing it around, still pointing the gun in your face. This vacation has been ruined.

mnemonics.meaning: People who loiter around the temple are probably just trying to wait. They don't mean to look like they're up to no good, but it's hard to wait without looking suspicious when you're waiting outside a temple. Imagine waiting outside a temple. People are giving you looks. People think you're loitering, not just waiting innocently.
mnemonics.reading: As you wait outside the temple, you can't help but adjust your tie (たい). When you wait you get nervous, and when you get nervous you fidget. So now you're messing with your tie a whole bunch. Imagine adjusting your tie as you wait. Oh no, now even more people are staring at you. The tie thing is making you look even more suspicious!

mnemonics.meaning: After a tsunami, any plate left out in the sun will be sure to get warm. The tsunami knocked this plate out of the kitchen, and now it’s just sitting outside in the sun. The sun heats things, so the plate is getting really warm. Right after the tsunami, this plate was wet, but the sun is warming and drying the plate. Imagine looking at the plate and seeing the beads of water evaporate off it as it warms up. Feel the warm steam on your face as this happens.
mnemonics.reading: The plate starts to get so warm that you could fry an onion (おん) on it. Who doesn’t love fried onions? That plate sure is warm enough, so start cookin’ ‘em! Imagine yourself frying onions on this plate warmed by the sun. Smell the onion smell as the onion fumes get into your eyes and your sinuses. It makes your eyes water as you are very sensitive to onions.

mnemonics.meaning: There are sheep right before your eyes, because they just love what you wear. It's a little known fact that sheep are fashionistas, and they arrive daily to admire your style. These sheep are so stylish they wear their tail to one side - in the latest fashion (check out the sheep radical - the tail is sweeping stylishly to the left!). Imagine all the chic sheep lining up to check out your style, with their carefully coiffed left-hanging tails!
mnemonics.reading: More sheep arrive every day to admire the clothes you're wearing. You use a chalk (ちゃく) board to keep count of how many sheep come by each day. Imagine yourself chalking up a line on a chalk board for each sheep that comes to admire you.

mnemonics.meaning: The lively moves you make are actions. They're the activities you do every day to stay fit and healthy!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: クリステンは、週末はコスプレイヤーとして活動しています。
Kristen is an active cosplayer on weekends.
午前と午後は大学で生物学を勉強し、夕方からはしゅう教活動をしています。
I study biology in the mornings and afternoons at college, and in the late afternoon, I engage in religious activities.
活動動詞とは動詞を相の観点から四つに分けた内の一つです。
Action verbs are one of the four verb types categorized from the aspect perspective.

mnemonics.meaning: When you go to move you're actually making an action. It's these behaviors when you go and move that determine what people think about you.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: これはあなたの行動がまねいたけっかです。
This is the result of your conduct.
いつもコウイチの行動パターンは決まっている。
Koichi's behavioral patterns are always the same.
あの人は発言と行動が一致していないからいつも惑わされて困る。
What they say and what they do don't match up, so I always have a hard time and get confused.

mnemonics.meaning: Put aside your steampunk blimp fantasies for a moment. A sky harbor is an airport, nothing more.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: この間、成田空港で大げんかをしているカップルを見ました。
I saw a couple having a huge fight at Narita Airport the other day.
おむつがえシートのあるトイレはこの空港にありますか？
Are there bathrooms with changing tables in this airport?
空港で借りた車の中に、パスポートを忘れた気がする。
I think I left my passport in the car I rented at the airport.

mnemonics.meaning: You've seen 飲む, so you know this has to do with drinking alcohol. Someone who's known as someone who drinks alcohol is an alcoholic, a boozer, or a drunkard.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the vocab words お酒 and 飲む combined together into one. You can guess it's a kun'yomi reading because of the み on the end of 飲, which should make you think back to vocab words that use these kanji and the kun'yomi readings. If you can do that, you can read this word (and many others, probably!).

sentences: 子どものくせにスルメがすきだなんて、こりゃぁこの子はしょう来酒飲みになるねぇ。
He likes dried cuttlefish, even though he is a kid, eh? He could be a boozer in the future.
コウイチはお酒は好きだけど、酒飲みってほどじゃあないですよ。
Koichi likes drinking, but he isn't like an alcoholic.
彼は大酒飲みだが、赤ワインが苦手だ。
He’s a heavy drinker but he doesn’t like red wine.

mnemonics.meaning: All members means all members. This is also a fancy way to say everybody.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 全員男せいです。
They are all males.
トーフグの社員は、全員がベーコンソムリエのしけんを受けることになりました。
They decided that every Tofugu employee will take the bacon sommelier exam.
全員がさんかするのはむずかしそうですね。
Looks like it'll be difficult for everyone to make it, yeah?

mnemonics.meaning: A moving thing... think about the "things" that move. Technically it could be a lot of things (aka basically anything), but in this case we are talking about moving living things. We won't include humans, because humans are too good to be called things. This refers to animals instead.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 動物は苦手なんです。
I don't like animals.
何か動物はかっていますか。
Do you have any animals?
コウイチがトーフグ動物園に100匹の重要な動物を集めてパーティーを開催したんだけど、何故か私は招待されなかったんだよね。私もコウイチにとっての重要動物の一匹だと思っていたんだけど。
Koichi hosted a party at the Tofugu Zoo for one hundred very important animals and for some reason, I wasn’t invited. I thought I was one of the VIA to him too.

mnemonics.meaning: The chirp voice is a sound an animal makes. Sure, it works for birds (which chirp), but it also works with most other animals as well. So, we call this an animal cry.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are those that you learned with the kanji. 声 gets changed to ごえ, though, so take note of that in your head. Perhaps you can imagine an animal that does a "GOEEEEE" cry.

sentences: きりんの鳴き声を聞いたことがありますか。
Have you ever heard what a giraffe sounds like?
外からコウイチの声が聞こえると思ったら、小鳥の鳴き声だった。
I thought I heard Koichi outside, but it was a little bird's chirps.
自動販売機の下から子犬の鳴き声が聞こえるんです。
I hear a puppy barking under the vending machine.

mnemonics.meaning: The hand (or person, as you know 手 often refers to a person) that wins gets to do as one pleases without regard for anyone else.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this is weird. It's all kun'yomi, which luckily you've seen before, but still strange. I guess when you do as one pleases you can read kanji however you want, in this case the kun'yomi readings. Do note that there's a small っ in there before, presumably to connect the two readings of the two kanji together.

sentences: ほんと、勝手だよね！
You are so selfish!
勝手なことばっかり言わないでよ！
Don't say whatever you want.
「サーモン！フグは五回も浮気したんだよ。そんな男のこと、信じちゃダメだってば。」「分かってるんだけど、でも、彼、私がいないと生きていけないって言うの。」「じゃあ、もう、勝手にすれば！」
"Salmon! Fugu cheated on you five times. Never trust a guy like that." "I know… but he says he can’t live without me." "Well, suit yourself then!"

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of bad? It's also bad.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  Do you know how in the Mario universe all the bad versions are called "WARU" (わる)? For example: "WARUIJI" and "WARIO." That's because they are bad. They come from this kanji. So, if you ever need to remember this reading, just think back to Wario and Waruigi.

sentences: この食べ放だいのすし屋のせっ客は、しんじられないほど悪い。
This all-you-can-eat sushi restaurant's customer service is unbelievably bad.
悪いけど、この野さいちょっと蒸しといてくれない？
Sorry to bother you, but can you steam these veggies for me?
牛乳は悪くなっていたけど、俺は気にしなかった。
The milk went bad, but I didn’t care.

mnemonics.meaning: A bad person is a bad person.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: あいつは悪人だが、ガーデニングがしゅ味なんだ。
He is a villain, but his hobby is gardening.
コウイチは悪人をえんじているだけだよ。
Koichi is just playing an evildoer.
お前、本当に善人と悪人を区別することが可能だと思っているのか？
Do you really think it’s possible to differentiate between good people and bad people?

mnemonics.meaning: Field Sphere! The greatest sport to grace this earth since a very similar (aka the same) sport, baseball. Think about it, you play on a field and you use a little sphere. Awesome!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: これから、プロ野球のし合を見に行くところなんです。
We are just about to go to a professional baseball game.
野球は好きだけど、野球部は体育会けいって聞いたから入りたくないんだよ。
I like baseball, but I heard you have to act like you're in the army if you belong to the baseball club, so I don't want to join it.
野球をしている時に膝を骨折しちゃったんだよね。
I fractured my knee while playing baseball.

mnemonics.meaning: A thing you drink is a beverage.
mnemonics.reading: These are both the kun'yomi readings. You've learned them already, so you already know how to read this word!

sentences: コウイチの飲んでいる飲み物は何ですか？
What's the drink that Koichi's drinking?
にんしん中は、アルコールをふくんだ飲み物は飲んではいけない。
Beverages containing alcohol shouldn't be drunk during pregnancy.
「何か冷たい飲み物はいかがですか？」「それでは、牛乳パックを二本頂けますか？」
"Would you like something cold to drink?" "Well then, could I have two cartons of milk?"

mnemonics.meaning: Your tribe's blood (lots of inbreeding) are the blood of your relatives. These are blood relatives.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: おそうしきの後に、血族の集まりがあります。
After the funeral, we will have a gathering of blood relatives.
コウイチの血族は、みんなとても身長が高い。
Koichi's blood relatives are all tall.
私の父は血族じゃないが、それでも本当の父のように思っている。
My dad isn’t a blood relative but I still think of him as my real dad.

mnemonics.meaning: Who is part parent to you? Your boss! They make it so you can take care of yourself by paying you, don't they? They'll break the legs of someone who crosses you. But they won't help you get back to sleep after you have nightmares. So they're only part like a parent.
mnemonics.reading: This word consists of the kun'yomi reading for 親 and the on'yomi reading for 分. You've learned both of these so you should be able to read this already!

sentences: 地下道でヤクザの親分とすれちがったんだ。
I walked by a yakuza kingpin in the underpass.
コウイチとビエトではどちらが親分でどちらが子分ですか。
Between Koichi and Viet, which is the boss and which is the henchman?
親分にバレたら大目玉を食らうぞ。
The chief will chew us out if we let it slip.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You smell someone's icky (いき) breath. It's gross. Your skin crawls and your eyes roll back in your head from the icky, icky smell. You might die.

sentences: あんたの息、死ぬほどくさいよ。
Your breath is so stinky that I could die.
びっくりしすぎて、息が止まるかと思ったよ。
You knocked the breath out of me!
水中で息はしないでください。
Please do not breathe underwater.

mnemonics.meaning: Selling merchandise is business, commerce, or trade.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You've learned them both already!

sentences: 一しょに商売して一もうけしようぜ！
Let's go into business and make a fortune together!
最近はあのコンビニのせいで、商売あがったりだね。
Business has dried up recently because of that convenience store.
学校卒業後に商売を始めたんですが、すぐに商売をすることは簡単ではないことを学びました。
After leaving school I went into business for myself, but I soon learned that running a business is no easy task.

mnemonics.meaning: The actions and things you have to 心配 about are your cares and worries.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the reading of 心配 (which you've hopefully gotten down okay by now) and 事 using the (こと) reading. It is rendaku'd, as well, so beware of the ごと (just another 心配事, ammiright?).

sentences: 心配事をわらいとばしてくれてありがとう。
Thank you for laughing my cares away.
なんだか心配事があるみたいだよ。
Apparently he's got some worries.
私の一番の心配事は、町に降り落ちる火山灰です。
My biggest worry is volcanic ash falling over the city.

mnemonics.meaning: A tooth bug... Luckily, it's not some bug living in your tooth, though you can see why someone might think this is what happens. A tooth with a "bug" in it is a tooth with a cavity.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are both kun'yomi, but those are the readings you learned with these kanji. Notice that は turns to ば, though. Presumably this is because you might yell out "BAH!" when you find out you have a cavity.

sentences: 今日、歯医者で虫歯をぬいてもらいました。
Today, I had my decayed tooth extracted at the dentist.
虫歯のげんいんであるミュータンスきんは子どもの成長とともにまわりの大人からうつってしまいます。
Streptococcus mutans bacteria, the cause of tooth decay, can be transferred from adults to the kids around them as they grow up.
虫歯がいっぱいあるんだけど、歯科保険が無いので、治療代を捻出することができないんだ。
I have so many cavities but I don’t have dental insurance and I can’t afford to get them treated.

mnemonics.meaning: The ordinal prefix number two chapter has a much simpler way of describing it, which is chapter two.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 第一章はおもしろかったけど、第二章はいまいちだった。
Chapter one was good, but two was meh.
人生の第二章のまく開けですね。
This is gonna be the second chapter of your life, yeah?
まじで？君もその本読んでるの？俺、昨日ちょうど第二章読み終わったところなんだけど。もしそれより先に進んでるなら、何も言わないでね。
No way! Are you reading that book too? I’ve just finished chapter two. Don’t tell me anything if you’re farther than me.

mnemonics.meaning: If you have a spirit of sunshine you're a really cheerful person.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: りょう理上手で子ども好きで陽気なおくさんがいるなんて、お前は本当にしあわせものだよ。
You are really blessed to have such a cheerful wife who's good at cooking and loves her children.
はるの陽気にさそわれて、いつの間にかねむってしまっていました。
I got carried away by the warm spring weather and fell asleep before I knew it.
うちの家族は貧乏だが陽気だ。
My family is poor but jovial.

mnemonics.meaning: Don't think of this as a juvenile talk. Think of 話 the vocab word, which means "story." If you do that, you get a "juvenile story." What's a juvenile story? It's a children's story.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: この童話、意外と泣けるんだよね。
This fairy tale will actually make you cry.
やっと、童話のしっぴつに、本気モードになってきました。
I'm finally getting serious about writing children's stories.
宮沢賢治の童話「祭の晩」は、私が子供の頃大好きなお話でした。
Miyazawa Kenji’s fairy tale "Night of the Festival" was my favorite story when I was a child.

mnemonics.meaning: The sound reading. What could this be...? Wait a sec, think to Japanese and kanji. What's the reading that uses sounds from another place, specifically China? That's the Chinese reading, aka the on'yomi. Sounds familiar?
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 音 is the 音読み. 読み uses the kun'yomi, though, strangely. Way to mess up the one word that should be all on'yomi, Japan. Way. To. Go.

sentences: この漢字の音読みって何だっけ？
What was the on'yomi for this kanji again?
初めて見た地名はふ通は音読みしちゃうよね。
We usually read place names that we see for the first time with on'yomi.
日本語の音読みと訓読みの違いは何ですか？
What’s the difference between the Chinese reading and the Japanese reading in the Japanese language?

mnemonics.meaning: When metropolises meet they become a city. Usually a nice big one.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 都会のいそがしい生活にはもううんざりだよ。
I'm fed up with the busy urban life.
これだから都会育ちはきらいなんだよ！
This is why I don't like city-bred people.
こんな田舎じゃなく、私は都会で働きたいのよ。
I want to work in the city, not in the countryside like this.

mnemonics.meaning: A metropolis city is a city. When you're referring to just a plain ol' city, sans name, you can use this word.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: このコウイチのどうぞうは、この都市のシンボルになりました。
This bronze statue of Koichi has become the symbol of this city.
いなかよりも、都市での生活の方がいいですね。
I prefer life in the city as opposed to life in the countryside.
何かおもしろい都市伝説を知っていますか？
Do you know any interesting urban legends?

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of cold? It's cold.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading which you learned with the kanji (Samurai (さむ)). Remember?

sentences: 寒すぎてふとんから出られない。
It's too cold to get out of bed.
この寒い中、一時間もバスを待たなきゃならなかったんだよ。
I had to wait an hour in this cold for the bus.
僕がハワイに行くのは、寒さから逃れるためだけではなく家族に会うためでもあります。
I’m going to Hawaii not only to escape the cold, but to see my family.

mnemonics.meaning: A "company" (会社) member is someone who works at a company. This is a company employee. There are many of these in Japan. Most of them are drunk.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: わたしの夫は、ごくふ通の会社員です。
My husband is just an ordinary office worker.
わたしたちはみんな、会社員である前に、一人の人間なんですよ。
We're people before we are employees.
あの会社員は麻薬所持で逮捕された。
That employee got busted for drug possession.

mnemonics.meaning: When you're talking or writing a paper, the part that falls at the end is the conclusion.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

sentences: 落ちをじゃまされてムカついた。
I was interrupted before I said the punch line and I got annoyed.
そういう落ちだったのね。
That was the outcome, huh?
あいつの話には落ちが無いんだよな。
His speech didn't have much of a conclusion.

mnemonics.meaning: This will be easier if you've seen or heard of daikon before. It's a really big root in the ground that's pretty delicious. It's known as daikon in the grocery stores for the most part, though occasionally you'll see it as Japanese radish instead.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. 大 uses the だい reading because if you try to put the whole thing in your mouth at once you'll probably end up choking and dying.

sentences: 一度、大根を育ててみようとしたんですが、全部かれてしまったんです。
I've tried to grow daikon once, but they all withered and died.
うちの家族は、クリスマスの時期にくつ下とかんそうさせた大根をぶら下げるんだ。
My family hangs up stockings and dried Japanese radishes for the Christmas season.
おお、これいいんじゃねえ？めちゃくちゃいい大根だよ。お前も、一本欲しいか？
Hey, check it out! These are really nice Japanese radishes. Do you want one of these too?

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of deep? It's also deep.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. Because the reading sounds just like a dirty word, and there may be innocent children about, I'll let you come up with your own mnemonic for this one. Maybe someone pushes you into a deep hole that will surely kill you so you yell something out as you fall down it?

sentences: 水深が急に深くなりましたね。
The water suddenly got deep, eh?
コウイチがデスクで深いため息をついてるのを見たんだけど、何かあったの？
I saw Koichi letting out a deep sigh, has something happened?
魚たちが、親や兄弟、高校時代の友人たちとの深い繋がりを保っていることが多いって、本当ですか？
Is it true that fish tend to maintain a deep connection with their parents, siblings, and high school friends?

mnemonics.meaning: The most deep is the deepest.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 日本で最深な地下鉄は、地下48ｍの場所がある大え戸線です。
Japan's deepest subway line is the Oedo line, which goes as low as 48 meters below ground.
しっとは人間の最深のつみだ。
Jealousy is the deepest sin of human sins.
サーモンと俺は、光が到達できる海の最深部に位置するロマンチックな秘密の洞穴で、結婚式をあげた。
Salmon and I had our wedding ceremony in a romantic hidden cave located at the deepest part of the ocean that light can still reach.

mnemonics.meaning: You know that a 医者 is a doctor. So what is a tooth doctor? A dentist. Seriously, don't forget to floss. 歯医者 hate when you forget to floss.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 半年に一度は歯医者に行った方がいい。
It's better to go see a dentist at least once every six months.
花田さんは、この歯医者にはもっ体ないよ。
Ms. Handa is too good for this dentist.
彼はただ不良に憧れてるだけだと思うよ。絶対に本物の不良にはならないね。だって、歯医者さんに行くのですら怖がってるんだよ！
I think he’s just a wannabe delinquent. I doubt he’ll end up being a real one because he’s still afraid of going to the dentist.

mnemonics.meaning: What is something that will first extinguish something and then change it? One thing I can think of is your body. It takes in food, extinguishes it in your stomach, then changes it into things your body can use (and then excrete). That's why this "extinguish-change" process is your digestion.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: このくすりは、消化をそく進してくれます。
This medicine will stimulate your digestion.
コウイチは下り気味だから、消化の良いものを食べさせてあげてね。
Koichi's having a touch of diarrhea, so please have him eat something easy to digest.
昼に食べたラーメンをまだ消化しきっていない。
I haven’t finished digesting the ramen I ate for lunch.

mnemonics.meaning: Something that is two times is double (or it is just simply two times). Of course, this all works with things like 三倍, 百倍, and 四十二倍 as well.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: このかぶのかぶかはたったの二日で二倍になった。
This stock's price doubled just in two days.
めんつゆを二倍にうすめるのを忘れないでください。
Don't forget to dilute the noodle soup base two times.
うわ！君のお兄さんって、君の二倍の体重があるんだね！
Wow! Your brother weighs twice as much as you, huh?

mnemonics.meaning: You know that 運転 has to do with driving, right? And you know that 手 often has to do with a person doing something in words like these. So, a person who does driving is what? A driver.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is all on'yomi, because it's jukugo. You should know the on'yomi reading of 手 by now just by seeing similar word patterns to this one.

sentences: タクシーに乗ったら運転手がトーフグのコウイチだった。
When I took the taxi, the driver happened to be Tofugu's Koichi.
バスの運転手と言い争いになってしまった。
I ended up getting in an argument with the bus driver.
運転手は大丈夫だったみたいだけど、車は事故でめちゃくちゃになっていたよ。
The driver seemed okay but his car was totaled in the accident.

mnemonics.meaning: The company members are the employees and the staff.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 全社員がコウイチと仲良くするためのイロハを心えている。
All of the staff know the ABCs of getting along with Koichi.
れいの社員さんとは最近どうなの？仲直りはできた？
How are things with that employee lately? Patch things up yet?
この会社の社員は、全員奇抜で素晴らしい。
The employees in this company are all weird and wonderful.

mnemonics.meaning: A peoples tribe (or tribe of peoples) is a group that all stick together. They are one single ethnic group. What's your 民族?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: わたしは民族のアイデンティティーを失いたくありません。
I don't want to lose my racial identity.
この民族は、とてもしん重なことでよく知られている。
This ethnic group is known for being very cautious.
インドには多様な民族がいますが、みんながみんなカレーを食べるのでしょうか。
India has a lot of ethnic diversity but I wonder if all of them still eat curry.

mnemonics.meaning: When you carry your movements (or carry something along with your movements, like weights, for example) you are doing exercise. Speaking of which, perhaps you've been studying kanji a little too much lately. Time to get up and do some squats.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 最近、運動不足気味です。
I feel like I haven't had enough exercise recently.
運動したいけど、時間がないんだよね。
I want to exercise, but I don't have time.
私は読書よりも運動の方が好きなので、本も、新聞も、雑誌も読みません。
I read neither books, nor newspapers, nor magazines because I like exercising more than reading.

mnemonics.meaning: For a period of time you have to wait. During this waiting period, you are expecting or anticipating something to happen. Waiting, expecting, waiting, expecting...
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あの大学院生には、もっと期待してたのに。
I expected more from the grad student.
この前わざわざ日本からとりよせた新しいおやつは期待外れでした。
The new snack that I bought and had sent all the way from Japan the other day was not as good as I anticipated.
ウォール・ストリートは常にトップレベルの人材を求めていますが、コウイチならきっとそこでも期待に応えられると思います。
Wall Street always needs top-level talent and I’m pretty sure that Koichi will be able to live up to those expectations.

mnemonics.meaning: The leaf that falls are fallen leaves.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this one is a bit strange. You'll have to pull from your knowledge of 落ちる and use that for the first half. Then, 葉 is rendaku'd to ば. Because, when a leaf falls, Scrooge says "BAH! Humbug!" (probably because he's losing money).

sentences: 目の前には、落ち葉のじゅうたんが広がっていました。
There was a carpet of fallen leaves that stretched out around us.
落ち葉をひろって天ぷらにしました。
I picked up some fallen leaves and made tempura with them.
「聞いてよ。最初は、お姉ちゃんの彼氏だから、フグと仲良くしようとしてただけだったの。でも、次々にいろんなことが重なって、知らない間に、お…落ち葉を一緒に熊手で集めてたの。」「ツ…ツナったら、なんてことなの。」「サーモン、待って。一度だけよ。それに、私は何とも思わなかったわ。」

"Look, when it started I was just trying to be nice to Fugu because he was my big sister’s boyfriend. Then, one thing led to another and before I knew it, we were... raking fallen leaves together." "T-Tuna. Why would you do that?" "Salmon, wait. We only did it once. It didn’t mean anything to me."

mnemonics.meaning: Your house tribe is your family. They live in the same house as you and they're part of your "tribe." This is closer than family, though (depending on how you look at family). This is your immediate family because these are the people you live with and give birth to, etc.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: わたしの家族は、庭でキュウリやトマト、ズッキーニなどたくさんの野さいを育てています。
My family grows a lot of vegetables in our garden, things like cucumbers, tomatoes, and zucchinis.
家族がなくなった場合、そのじゅう業いんは死亡発生日の次の出きん日から三日間けいちょう休かを取得できます。

When a member of an employee's immediate family dies, the employee is entitled to leave on any normal working day that falls within the three-day period immediately following the day the death occurred.
今度、俺の日本への家族旅行のことを君に話したいな。
I wanna tell you about my family vacation in Japan some time.

mnemonics.meaning: The essence of your house and garden is your family, household, or home.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: いつかはけっこんして、あたたかい家庭をきずきたいと思っています。
I want to get married and build a loving home someday.
わたしのしゅ味は、かく家庭から出るゴミをす手でしゅう集することです。
My hobby is to pick up each household member's waste with my bare hands.
日本女性と比べると、外国の女性は家庭の時間と仕事の時間を分けることには、かなり厳格です。
Compared to Japanese women, foreign women tend to be pretty strict about separating family time and working time.

mnemonics.meaning: Your father parent is your father.
mnemonics.reading: The reading here is pretty weird. It's all kun'yomi. My guess is this translates literally to "father parent" (two different words, therefore uses the other readings). You should know the readings of these two separate words, though. It is 父 (ちち) and 親 (おや).

sentences: わたしの父親はレスラーです。
My father is a wrestler.
今朝、父親が部屋でこっそりオナラをするのを見てしまいました。
This morning, I saw my father secretly farting in his room.
うちの家族はみんな父親のことが大好きです。
Everyone in my family loves my dad.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: While at a festival, a guy named Matt has to go to the bathroom. Matt’s urine (まつり) has been filling up his bladder ever since he began drinking that 64oz cup of soda. Matt’s urine is ready to bust out at any moment. He really has to go to the bathroom. This word can also be written 祭り, and the pronunciation stays the same.

sentences: 祭の屋台で売ってるりんごあめがすきなんです。
I like the candy apples they sell from food stands at festivals.
こないだの日よう日のお祭りで、かれ氏と初めて手をつないだんだ。
At the last Sunday's festival, me and my boyfriend held hands for the first time.
日本の多くのお祭は、仏教や神道と結びついています。
Many Japanese festivals have connections to Buddhism or Shintoism.

mnemonics.meaning: The one floor is the first floor (or floor one). Pretty simple.  Unless you're British, that is. For you this is the ground floor!
mnemonics.reading: The reading is on'yomi because it's a jukugo kanji. Be careful of the 一 though. It gets shortened and has a little っ in there.

sentences: ヘビたちは一階でかっているんですか？
Do you have those snakes on the first floor?
一階はまだまだびちょびちょだよ。
The ground floor is still wet.
「荷物はどこに置いたらいいかな？」「一階でも、二階でも、下でも、どこでも。あなたの好きなところに置いてくれていいよ。」「わかったわ。有難う。」
"Where should I put my stuff?" "Here, the first floor, the second floor, anywhere. You can put them any place you’d like." "Okay. Thank you."

mnemonics.meaning: The ordinal number prefix one rank. Basically, this means "first rank" or first place.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: トーフグはユニークな日本語学習教ざいとして、五年れんぞく第一位のざをかくとくしています。
Tofugu got first place five consecutive times in tournaments for unique Japanese learning tools.
トーフグチームの中で一番げん付乗りまわしていてほしい人第一位はわたしてきにはクリステンなんだよね。
Out of the whole Tofugu team, I personally want Kristen to drive around in a moped the most.
あきらが入社するまで、ヒロは五年続けて、社内で売り上げ第一位だった。
Hiro had been the top sales person in the company for five consecutive years until Akira joined the company.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a weird one. You have one stream. This is first rate stream material we have here, though. If you think about it, if you only have one stream (instead of a ton of streams), you can put all your effort and energy into it. When you do that, you're making sure it is a first rate stream in terms of quality and anything else.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: さすが、一流のピアニストは違うね。
That's something only first-rate pianists can do.
わたしの妹は、お金持ちで一流のしんしとこいに落ちました。
My sister fell in love with a wealthy, first-class gentleman.
これでコウイチは一流社会の仲間入りだ。たくさんのセレブに会ったり、シャンパンパーティにもすぐ行き始めるだろう。
Koichi is now a member of the upperclass. He will meet a bunch of celebrities and start going to champagne parties soon.

mnemonics.meaning: You know that the kanji refers to a floor (as in the "fifth floor"). This word represents the version that comes after a number, shown with a 〜. Essentially, this has the same meaning as the kanji you learned, making it nice and easy.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Don't type in the 〜 or you'll get it wrong!

sentences: 「何階ですか？」「四階をおねがいします。」「このエレベーターはその階には止まりませんよ。」
"Which floor?" "Fourth please." "This elevator doesn't stop on that floor."
コウイチは、九十九階だてのマンションの最上階に住んでいます。
Koichi lives on the top floor of a ninety-nine story apartment building.
このアパートの十三階に住んでいます。
I live on the thirteenth floor of this apartment.

mnemonics.meaning: You know that 四十二 means "forty two." So, as long as you know floor you'll know this means forty-second floor.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 四十二階まで競争よ！
Let's race to the forty-second floor!
コウイチは東京に四十二階だてのマンションを持っている。
Koichi owns a forty-two-story condominium in Tokyo.
引っ越しって、色々事務手続きがあって結構面倒くさい上に、対応の悪い担当者とかもいたりするよね。でも、今回の引っ越しで最悪だったのは、引っ越しの日にエレベーターが故障中だったことだよ。俺の部屋、四十二階なのに。

It’s pretty annoying that there’s a lot of bureaucratic red tape involved in moving, and to make matters worse, sometimes the person in charge has an attitude problem. However, the worst part of my moving this time was that the elevator was out of service when I moved in and my apartment was on the forty-second floor.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. You can add the meaning yard to your memory bank as well, if you'd like.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You look at your garden. It doesn't meet your expectations so you decide it's time to get a newer (にわ) garden. Tear it all down, folks! Getting a newer garden, here!

sentences: 今日は、庭の地ならしをします。
I'm gonna level the ground in the yard today.
庭で家庭さいえんをしています。
I grow vegetables in our garden.
うちには美しい庭があるんだが、隣の人の鶏がいつも花を食べてしまうんだ。
I have a beautiful garden but my neighbor’s chickens keep eating my flowers.

mnemonics.meaning: This is the noun version of the kanji gather, so it means gathering.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

sentences: 今日は研究室の集まりがある。
There’s a get-together with people from the lab today.
なんか今日の飲み会、集まりも悪かったし、グダグダだったね。
Not many people showed up at today's drinking party and it was also very disorganized, eh?
正月の集まりに弟が彼女を連れてきやがった。
My younger brother brought his girlfriend to our New Year's gathering.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how you learned that 大学院 means "graduate school" and 大学生 means "college student?" Well smush them together and you have a  graduate student!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この大学院生は、えんげいが上手だ。
This graduate student has a green thumb.
あのまんるいホームランを打ったせん手、げん役の大学院生らしいよ。
That player who hit a grand slam is apparently an actual grad student.
大学院生ってどんなことをするんですか？
What kinds of things do graduate students do?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This is a single kanji with no okurigana, so it's using the kun'yomi reading. You don't know this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You go down to the harbor and speak the secret password me natto (みなと) to buy some fresh natto. Imagine the salty air hitting your face as you whisper, "me natto." Now eat that yummy natto by the water! Mmmm!

sentences: ベラクルスという港町に行ってみたいです。
I would like to visit the port city of Veracruz.
ごう雨のため、港への道は通行止めになっています。
Due to heavy rain, the road to the harbor is closed.
不思議な船が港に漂着した。
There was a mysterious ship drifting in the harbor.

mnemonics.meaning: You've seen 聞く by now hopefully. This is similar, but instead of meaning "to hear" it means hearable (or to be audible). Just think about that こえ hanging off there as the voice you can hear.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 聞く, so if you know the reading of that word, you can apply it here.

sentences: 聞こえたんだったら、ちゃんと返事してよ！
If you could hear me, you should've said something!
オナラ、聞こえちゃったよね？
You heard my fart, didn't you?
きつい言い方に聞こえることは分かってるんだけど、つまらない言い訳はしたくないの。
I understand it sounds harsh, but I’m up to my neck in lame excuses.

mnemonics.meaning: The wide island... this isn't helpful on its own, but this wide island is Hiroshima (heard of it?). When you do the reading it will make more sense.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the kun'yomi readings of both of these which is what you learned with the individual kanji. Just make sure you know those readings and you'll be able to read this.

sentences: 広島に、登山にいい山はありますか？
Are there good mountains to climb in Hiroshima?
広島空港から市バスで市内に向かってるところです。
I'm heading into the city from Hiroshima airport by city bus.
広島と長崎に投下された原爆は、一瞬で十万人以上の人々の命を奪った。
The atomic bombs dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki instantly killed more than 100,000 people.

mnemonics.meaning: A warm spring (like the water kind of spring) is a hot spring. These are really nice. You should go to them in Japan.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: この温泉は、タトゥーのある人も入よくできます。
This onsen is open for people with tattoos too.
かるく運動してあせを流した後、温泉に入ろう。
Let's go to the hot springs after sweating a little bit from some light exercise.
私の父も母も温泉が好きじゃありません。
Neither my dad nor mom likes hot springs.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: お湯であらってみたら、落ちるかもしれないよ。
If you wash it with hot water, you might be able to remove it.
コウイチは大きい方をした後、お湯と石けんで手をあらいます。
After going number two, Koichi washes his hands with hot water and soap.
お湯を沸かしてくれないか？
Could you boil some water?

mnemonics.meaning: This is the adjective form of hot... but we're going to call it hot weather. Why? Because there's a difference between something that's hot and the weather or atmosphere being hot. This is that kind of hot, as in..."Damn, man, it's hot out here!"
mnemonics.reading: This uses the same reading as the one you learned with the kanji, so you're good to go here!

sentences: 暑すぎてとけそう。
It's so hot I'm about to melt.
日本では、このところ暑い日がつづいています。
It has been hot these days in Japan.
クソ暑いし蒸し蒸しするしたまんねぇな！この暑さでは寝られないよ。プールに行こうぜ！
It’s too hot and humid! I can’t sleep in this heat. Let’s go to the pool!

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well!
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the same reading as the one you learned with the kanji.  I certainly like that and I bet you do too.

sentences: 僕に任せろ。
Leave it to me.
医者から慰謝料をもらうというダジャレを作ったのは僕だ。
It was I who made the pun, "I get compensation from a doctor."
これは僕の缶珈琲だぞ！
This is my canned coffee!

mnemonics.meaning: You receive profit at every breath. What kind of profit is this? It's interest. As time goes by and as you take more breaths you gain more bank interest.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: もし利息の支はらいがおくれたら、ビエトがヤクザの友だちをつれてお前のところにやって来ると思うぜ。
If you miss the interest payment, Viet will probably bring some of his yakuza friends to your place.
コウイチは利息で生活できるぐらい十分なお金をぎん行にちょ金しています。
Koichi has enough money in the bank to live on his interest.
あいにく今、その質問に答えられる者がいないのですが、もしインターネットにアクセス可能なら利息のレートはそちらでもご確認頂けますよ。
I’m afraid there is no one here who can answer your question right now, but you can also check your interest rate online, if you can connect to the Internet.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: この島のはま辺では、水着は着用できません。
You can’t wear swimsuits on this island's beaches.
わたしの家内は、この島で一番の美人です。
My wife is the most beautiful woman on this island.
この島で一週間生活をしてもらいます。
I’m going to have you live on this island for a week.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how you learned that 文字 can mean "characters?" Well make a face out of those characters and you've made a kaomoji! ʅ(◔౪◔ ) ʃ
mnemonics.reading: This word consists of the kun'yomi reading for 顔 added to the jukugo word 文字 that you already learned. You've learned these readings before, so reading this word should be nice and easy!

sentences: 今の気持ちを顔文字で表してください。
Please express your current feelings with kaomoji.
ビエトがコウイチにあてた手紙を内しょで読んだら、全てが顔文字でかかれていた。
I secretly read Viet's letter to Koichi, but everything was written in kaomoji.
上司へのメールに顔文字を使うんじゃない！
Don’t use kaomoji when you’re emailing a superior!

mnemonics.meaning: The capital metropolis back in the day was Kyoto. Now of course the capital is Tokyo, but kanji doesn't know this. That's why Kyoto is the capital metropolis!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: JRの「そうだ、京都行こう」の広告を見て京都に行きたくなったが、そんなお金はなかった。
The JR ad "That's it! Let's go to Kyoto." made me want to go to Kyoto, but I didn't have that kind of money.
京都に行ったら、湯葉を食べたいです。
When I go to Kyoto, I want to eat tofu skin.
コウイチは本日は既に京都へ発ってしまいました。明日の朝一番に折り返しお電話をさせましょうか？
Koichi has already left for Kyoto today. Shall I have him call you back first thing tomorrow morning?

mnemonics.meaning: We've seen a few times where 電 refers to a train. They're big deals, after all, and use a ton of electricity. So, the end train for this word would refer to the last train.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 終電、何時だっけ？
What time was the last train?
もうすぐ終電だから、そろそろかえらなきゃ。
I've gotta go because it's almost time for the last train.
「もし終電に乗り遅れたら、いつでも電話してくれていいよ。」「有難う。覚えておくよ。」
"If you ever miss the last train, you can always call me." "Thanks, I’ll keep that in mind."

mnemonics.meaning: This takes the luck meaning from the kanji. Think of it this way: If you're "carrying" you're going to create your own luck. Now nobody will mess with you, kanji gangstah. You carry guns and have a ton of luck because of it.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji! How... shall I say... luck-filled?

sentences: 運が良ければ、トーフグのコウイチに会えるかもね。
If you're lucky, you may be able to meet Koichi from Tofugu.
たまたま運が良かっただけだよ。
I was just lucky.
こんなことで使い果たしたくはないけど、これで運を使い果たしちゃったかも。
I might have run out of luck though, and I don't want to use it up on something like this.

mnemonics.meaning: The origin stream, that's where everything comes from. That is the mainstream.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: このフグは、トーフ川本流のワニカニはしの下でつれました。
I caught this blowfish underneath the WaniKani bridge in the main stream of the Tofu River.
コウイチは、ファッションの本流に大きなえいきょうをあたえることで有名です。
Koichi is known for having a big influence on mainstream fashion.
日本文学の本流と言って、最初に思い浮かぶのは誰ですか。
When you say mainstream Japanese literature, who is the first author that comes to mind?

mnemonics.meaning: If you meet enough members you will become a member yourself!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あの会員はかなり心配しょうのようなんです。
That member seems to be a huge worrywart.
見えないかもしれませんが、そこにもう一人小さな会員がいるんですよ。
You may not be able to see it, but there's one more little member over there.
会員カードはお持ちですか。
Do you have a membership card?

mnemonics.meaning: A merchandise person is a merchant. You want to buy something or you just looking?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 商人の血がさわぎます。
As a merchant, I'm thrilled.
わたしの父は、おろし商人です。
My dad is a wholesale trader.
彼、私に自分は商人だって言ってたんだけど、でも実は貧乏なホームレスで、仕事はなんと空き缶収集だったの。
He told me that he was a shopkeeper, but I found out that he was actually a poor homeless man who supported himself by collecting empty cans.

mnemonics.meaning: The deep night is the middle of the night. It doesn't get any deeper than that before you start coming out of the night to start the next day.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: こんな深夜に、どうしたの？
What's up this late at night?
深夜に小ばらが空いてきた。
I got a bit hungry in the middle of the night.
環境難民となった熊たちは、新しい国で食べ物を探すため、深夜、国境を越えた。
The environmental refugee bears crossed the border late in the night to find something to eat in a new country.

mnemonics.meaning: The mother parent is the mother.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this is strange. It's the kun'yomi vocab reading, probably because the literal translation is "mother parent" and therefore consists of a couple words combined together into one concept. So, make sure you know the separate word readings of 母 and 親. If you do, you should be able to read this too.

sentences: 母親と仲直りがしたい。
I want to make up with my mother.
母親とそのかれ氏、気持ちがだんだんはなれていっちゃったみたいで、けっきょく別れたんだよね。
My mother and her boyfriend ended up breaking up because apparently they had been gradually growing apart.
「ごめんなさい。明日のランチ、キャンセルしなくちゃいけなくなったの。母親がちょっと体調崩しちゃって。」 「気にしないで。また今度、会いましょう。それより、お母様、早く良くなるといいわね。」
"I’m sorry but I have to cancel lunch tomorrow. My mother got sick." "It’s no big deal. Let’s meet another time. I hope your mom gets well soon."

mnemonics.meaning: Climb a mountain. That is mountain climbing.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note this uses the alternative と reading, not to be confused with とう (actually, very confusing, sorry!). Just imagine you cut your toe off with an ice pick while mountain climbing. You know it's a short と because your toe is now short. And さん becomes ざん thanks to our old friend rendaku.

sentences: ふじ山に登山してみたいです。
I want to try climbing Mt. Fuji.
もう登山はこりごりです。
I never want to climb a mountain again.
「登山に行くってのはどう？」「さあ、どうしようかなあ。」
"How about we go mountain climbing?" "Well I don’t know about that."

mnemonics.meaning: The day you have a festival is a national holiday. That way everyone can come to celebrate without worrying about going to school or work. This is also known as a festival day (pretty obvious, right?).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その祭日の予定はまだありません。
I don't have any plans for that festival day.
祭日なのに、仕事なの？
Do you have to work even though it's a national holiday?
祭日だってことを忘れていて、会社に来てしまった。
I forgot it was a holiday and I came to the office.

mnemonics.meaning: This one makes no sense (sorry!). When you join together with someone at a metropolis, you do it at your convenience. You're important, after all, so you just do what you want and make the other person wait in this giant metropolis while you move along leisurely. Imagine this, and keep thinking "at your convenience" as you walk about. This word is usually used in a nicer way, though. As in, "do it at your convenience!"
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 都 is an exception from what you learned with the kanji. To remember this, just think about someone who does something at their own convenience. They say, I'm going to go (つごう) where I want, when I want, at my own convenience. The 合 (ごう) part is a reading you know from the kanji, though, so if you can get to "to go" with the mnemonic, you should be able to put two and two together to know that it's a long vowel ごう.

sentences: 都合がつき次第、こちらかられんらくします。
I'll get in touch with you as soon as possible.
都合次第では、コウイチのけっこんしきはえん期になるかもしれません。
Depending on the circumstances, Koichi's wedding ceremony may be postponed.
「土曜日と日曜日、どちらの方が都合がいい？」「どちらでもいいよ。」
"Which day is convenient for you, Saturday or Sunday?" "It makes no difference to me."

mnemonics.meaning: The root of your energy. You have to dig deep into your energy, all the way to the origin and source of it, to have enough patience to deal with this dumb kid who's eating away at your not-root energy. It's all you have, and you need to use it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: これは根気のいる仕事だよな。
This job requires patience, huh?
ほとんどの失ぱいのげんいんは、根気のなさなんだよね。
The reason for failure in most cases is a lack of perseverance.
根気よく日本語の勉強を続けていれば、いつかはペラペラになれるさ。
Keep studying Japanese persistently and you’ll be fluent someday.

mnemonics.meaning: A period of time interval is still a period or interval of time.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: テスト期間中はあまりねれません。
I can't sleep much during exams.
わたしは人生のある期間を山おくですごした。
I spent a period of my life in a deep mountain.
コウイチの髭を期間限定で販売しています。
We're selling Koichi's mustache for a limited time only.

mnemonics.meaning: Plant things are plants or vegetation.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji.

sentences: コウイチは植物の言っている事が分かるらしい。
Apparently Koichi can understand what plants are saying.
これは、植物でできたふ葉土です。
This is mulch from the vegetation.
園芸の才能は無いけど植物を育てるのは好きなんですよ。
I don’t have a green thumb but I like to grow plants.

mnemonics.meaning: The root of your roof is still your roof. If it helps, imagine roots growing out of your roof. They protect you from the rain.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the kun'yomi readings. The kun'yomi for 根 is ね. For a mnemonic, we'll use the sound a horse makes, neigh (ね). Why is the horse neigh-ing? It's stuck on the roof.

sentences: 来年、屋根をしゅう理する必要があります。
We have to fix our roof next year.
屋根にあなが開いているので、雨もりしてるんですよ。
It's leaking because we have a hole in our roof.
お昼までに屋根の雪を取り除いて下さい。
Please clear the snow off the roof by noon.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: This is a magic root that turns you into a horse. You take a bite and let out a loud neigh (ね)!

sentences: この花の根は食べられますよ。
You can eat the roots of this flower.
このもんだいは相当根が深いようですね。
It seems that this problem has really deep roots.
彼は素敵な人だと思うかもしれないが、根がひどい男なのだ。
You might think he’s a great person but he’s really a horrible man at heart.

mnemonics.meaning: The root origin is the root of something. Possibly even more root than root, but we'll stick with root.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Careful, 本 is ぽん, which is a weird rendaku.

sentences: そもそも、根本から間ちがってるんだよ。
First of all, you are fundamentally wrong.
そのふうふは、子どもの教育についての根本の考え方が合わなかったんです。
That couple had fundamentally different ideas about their kid's education.
クリステンはベーコンを食べませんが、この問題の根本の原因はどこにあると思いますか？
Kristen doesn’t eat bacon; where do you think the root of this problem lies?

mnemonics.meaning: A member of a boat is called a sailor.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今日は夕方に船員さんがおむかえに来てくれるからね。
A seaman will come pick you up this evening, okay?
そ父は海ぐんの船員でした。
My grandfather was a sailor in the navy.
今日、あの船員がチェックアウトした部屋に、部屋を変えてもらえませんか？
Could I move into the room where that mariner checked out of today?

mnemonics.meaning: The study period of time isn't the pitiful amount of time you spend studying. It's something much bigger: the school term. Ugh, how much longer is this study period of time???
mnemonics.reading: The reading is on'yomi because it's a jukugo word but がく gets shortened to がっ, so be careful. Maybe you just wish the school term would get shorter which is why you shortened がく like that?

sentences: 次の学期にもフグと日本語と着物のクラスをとるつもりです。
I am planning to take Japanese and kimono classes with Fugu next semester as well.
この学期が終わったら、コウイチとコウイチ子はハワイでけっこんしきをあげる予定です。
After this term ends, Koichi and Koichiko will have their wedding ceremony in Hawaii.
学期末試験は三月なので、まだまだ勉強する時間はたっぷりあります。
Final exams are held in March so there's still plenty of time to prepare.

mnemonics.meaning: The two floor is the second floor. Going up!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 歯医者さんなら、このビルの二階にあります。
The dentist is on the second floor of this building.
二階だてのマイホームを買いました。
We bought a second story home.
毎日午後に二階にある同じ教室に行って、英語を二時間教えます。
Every afternoon I go to the same classroom on the second floor and teach two hours of English.

mnemonics.meaning: The shop member is someone who is a "member" (aka employed by) the shop. This is the shop staff.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 昔、あの店員の弟に家庭教しのバイトで英語を教えていました。
I used to have a part time job where I taught English to the younger brother of that clerk.
あの店員さん、とってもお茶目だったね。
That shop employee was a real kidder, wasn't he?
えっと、レジの順番待ちの列に並んでいる時に、ある店員さんが「万引きです！捕まえて！」と叫ぶのが聞こえたので、彼を捕まえたんです。
Well, while standing in the checkout line I heard one of the salespeople yell, "Shoplifter! Grab him!" so I grabbed him.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of short? It's short.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  What's a very short race? A midget car (みじか) race. Don't tell me you've never heard of midget car racing.

sentences: そのスカート、ちょっと短すぎるんじゃない？
Isn't that skirt a bit too short?
赤ちゃんが短い手足をバタバタさせてるのは本当にかわいい。
The baby's short, flailing arms and legs are so cute!
わぁ！あんたの尻尾が私より短いなんて、知らなかったわ。
Wah! I didn’t know your tail was shorter than mine.

mnemonics.meaning: The short period of time is the short term. You know not to think short term anyways, right? You're learning kanji, after all.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: まずは、短期の目ひょうをいくつか作ってみてください。
First, please set a few short-term goals.
こんな短期間でこんなにおぼえるとか、頭がパンクするっつーの。
I can't memorize this much in such a short period of time. My head is going to explode!
私は父に、短期的なコスト削減のためにリーダーシップ研修を縮小している企業は、一文惜しみの百知らずだと教えられました。
My father told me that companies that cut back on leadership training to save money in the short term are a penny wise and pound foolish.

mnemonics.meaning: The short sword is the short sword. What's another word for a short sword? It's a dagger.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: その短刀、どこで買ったの？
Where did you buy that tanto?
ビエトは、短刀を使ってとても上手にりょう理をします。
Viet cooks very well with a short sword.
私の父は、母に短刀で刺されて死にました。
My mother stabbed my father with a dagger and he died.

mnemonics.meaning: The breath child (that lets you release your breath when it's born) is a son. Nowadays it's cool to have a girl, but back in the day you wanted a son to carry on your underwater basket weaving legacy. That's why this is a son.
mnemonics.reading: The reading of this is messed up. 子 is こ, that should be okay. 息 is むす for some reason though. Why? Because you gave birth to a son, but he was a moose (むす). You better hold that breath again, because this is not what you wanted.

sentences: 息子が明日のしけんのために一夜づけしているため、今夜はとてもしずかだ。
Tonight is very quiet because my son is cramming for the exam tomorrow.
うちの息子は、こうりつてきに働いてだれよりも早くたい社するんだ。
My son works efficiently and goes home earlier than anyone else.
全くひどい息子をもったもんだよ。あいつは昨夜俺のケーキの残りをこっそり盗み食いしやがったんだ。
I have the most beastly son. He sneakily ate up the rest of my cake last night.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Another meaning I'm going to add is sports ball because this is the word used for balls in various sports (soccer, baseball, etc).
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're holding onto a sports ball in your hand, let's say it's a baseball for this mnemonic's sake. You throw it at your friend who's going to catch it. As it flies through the air, though, it transforms into a tomahawk (たま). Imagine your shock and fear as you see this happening, flying towards your friend! It's going to stick in his forehead. He can't catch this with his glove!  Also notice that it has the same reading as the vocab word 玉. So, if you know that one, you may know this one too! They're kind of similar. This can be read きゅう too, if you're talking about more of a globe sphere than the ball sphere you throw.

sentences: ああっ！球がバンカーに入っちゃったよ。
Dammit! I hit the ball into a bunker.
球の体せきをもとめる公しきって何だっけ？
What was the formula for the volume of a sphere?
ねぇ、新しい野球の球を買ったんだけど、一緒にキャッチボールしない？
Hey, I got a new baseball. Do you want to play catch with me?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're looking at a natural spring in the ground. Water is bubbling up, but then something changes. It looks a bit clogged... something is poking out. Then, all of a sudden, Mario flies out of the springs, falls in front of you and yells: "izumeeeee (いずみ), Mario!"

sentences: わたしたちは、泉からのわき水を飲んでいます。
We're drinking water from the spring.
その泉にはがちょうがたくさんいます。
There are a lot of geese in that spring.
わぁ！すごく綺麗。何か特別なダイエットでもしたの？それとも、若返りの泉でも見つけたとか？
Wow! You look beautiful! Did you go on a special diet? Or did you find the Fountain of Youth?

mnemonics.meaning: Something you wear, and wear again, is something you steadily wear. You do it so often, it's reliable. Also, if you wear something this much it's steadily wearing away too.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses on'yomi readings of the kanji you learned, twice. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その会社員は、いつも着々と仕事をこなしていた。
That office worker always got tasks done steadily.
プロジェクトは着々進んでいるようだね。
It seems like you're making steady progress on the project.
手はずは着々と整っていますよ。
The arrangements for it have been moving along steadily.

mnemonics.meaning: Hot water's energy isn't the hot water itself, it's what comes out of it (when it's boiling, for example). This is the steam and vapor.
mnemonics.reading: The ゆ part of the reading makes sense. The げ part for 気 is a bit of an exception, so here's a mnemonic to help with that: No creature likes steam and vapor more than geckos (げ). Geckos live in hot places, so wherever you see steam, you'll be sure to see at least one gecko nearby, if you look hard enough.

sentences: ビエトのおでこから出ている湯気、なんだかいいにおいがするんだよね。
The vapors coming out of Viet's forehead smell nice for some reason.
それ、まだ湯気が立つほどあついから、気を付けてね。
That's still steaming hot, so be careful.
美味しい寿司飯を作るには、しゃもじを使って、湯気が立つ炊きたての熱いごはんに酢を混ぜる必要があります。信じられないかもしれませんが、実際に米一粒一粒を潰さずに酢を混ぜるには技術が必要です。

To make good sushi rice, you need to mix vinegar into steaming hot, freshly cooked rice, using a paddle. Believe it or not, it actually takes skill to mix the vinegar into the rice without crushing the individual grains.

mnemonics.meaning: Your exertion is strong. You'd think this means you're working hard or something, but it means studies (like studies you have for a test or something). So for this, just imagine yourself exerting yourself really strongly on your homework. These are your studies / what you study.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: ありがとうございます！勉強になります。
Thank you so much. I've been learning a lot from you.
最近、だらけちゃってて、あんまりちゃんと勉強してないんだよね。
I've been slacking off and haven't been studying as much recently.
英語の勉強、頑張って下さいね。私も日本語をずっと勉強しているので苦労はよくわかります。
Keep up your English language studies. I’m always working on my Japanese too, so I know how hard it is.

mnemonics.meaning: The fat sunshine thing up in the sky... what is it called? Oh, that's right. It's the sun.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 太陽のようなコウイチのえ顔に、こいに落ちてしまいました。
I fell in love with Koichi's sunshine-like smile.
太陽の温度って何度ぐらいあるか知っていますか？
Do you happen to know what the sun's temperature is?
日本万国博覧会のシンボルは、岡本太郎が作った「太陽の塔」で、それは今も日本の大阪の吹田にある万博公園にそびえ立っています。
The symbol of Expo ’70 was the Tower of the Sun, created by Taro Okamoto, and it’s still standing in the Expo Commemoration Park in Suita, Osaka, Japan.

mnemonics.meaning: A rice paddy is used as a substitute for an island. Which island is it? That's right, Tashirojima. Imagine a rice paddy in the middle of the sea, standing in for Tashiro Island
mnemonics.reading: This is a place name and it uses the kun'yomi. You haven't learned this particular kun'yomi for 代 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: When you go to Tashirojima, make sure you visit the old woman. You know what woman I'm talking about, the one who starred on Murder she wrote (しろ). She writes a lot about cats now, I guess.

sentences: 田代島の人口は百人以下です。
The population of Tashirojima is less than one hundred.
田代島にはガソリンスタンドがありません。
There are no gas stations on Tashirojima.
最も有名な「猫島」といえば、日本の宮城県にある田代島という島です。
The most famous "cat island" is Tashiro Island in Japan's Miyagi prefecture.

mnemonics.meaning: The hot water of tea. That is part of the ceremony that goes into the tea ceremony.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are both the readings you learned with the kanji. Now you can spend a little more time drinking tea at a tea ceremony and a little less time trying to remember kanji readings.

sentences: 茶の湯の道具が買えるお店をさがしています。
I'm looking for a shop where I can buy tools for tea ceremonies.
この水は、茶の湯にてきした水として知られています。
This water is known to be good for tea ceremony.
茶の湯の世界には、「一つ一つの出会いを大切に」という意味の「一期一会」という言葉があります。この言葉は、映画「フォレスト・ガンプ」の副タイトルとしても使われました。
In the world of tea ceremonies there is a saying, "Ichi-go ichi-e," which means "to treasure every encounter." This saying was also used as the subtitle for Japan’s release of Forrest Gump.

mnemonics.meaning: The warm degrees is how many degrees warm it is in here. Of course, there can be very few warm degrees as well, making it very cold. What is all this? It's the temperature.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: アメリカ人と日本人って、温度のかんじ方がちがうと思いますか？
Do you think American and Japanese people feel temperature differently?
エアコンの温度を二十四度まで上げてもらえませんか？
Can you raise the temperature on the AC up to 24℃?
醸造中に天気や温度がほんの少し変化しただけで、酒の味に影響することがあるため、酒を作ることは非常に難しいと言われています。
It’s said to be very difficult to make sake because the slightest change in the weather or temperature during brewing can affect its taste.

mnemonics.meaning: The energy of the warmth will cause the temperature to go up and down. Energy goes up? Higher temperature because of more movement and activity. Energy goes down? Well, temperature gets colder and slower.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 気温が急に下がった。
The temperature fell suddenly.
今日の最高気温は四十度です。
Today's highest temperature will be 40 degrees.
朝ばんの気温のさがはげしいんです。
There is a large temperature gap between morning and night.

mnemonics.meaning: The earth sphere! It's where we live and the planet we call home. It's the earth!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 地球はお金では買えないよ。
You can not buy the Earth with money.
コウイチは今ごろ地球のうらがわで何をしてるんだろう。
I wonder what Koichi is doing right now, halfway around the globe.
地球という名前を考えたのは誰だ？
Who came up with the name Earth?

mnemonics.meaning: By now you should know that 終わる means "to end" or "to finish." So what is this noun-version of that word? It would be the end or the finish.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 終わる. So long as you know that word, you can learn this word's reading as well!

sentences: これで終わりだ。
This is the end.
終わり良ければ全て良し、でしょ？
All is well that ends well, right?
今週で仕事も終わりで、来週からはクリスマス休暇だー！あー、待ちきれない。
Work ends this week and Christmas holidays starts next week! Aww I can't wait for that.

mnemonics.meaning: The ordinal number prefix one refers to the first thing. This is the number one place you can get. In fact, it's simply the best.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 自分のけんこうが第一ですよ。
You should put your health first.
第一きぼうは二月十四日で、第二きぼうは二月二十一日です。
My first preference is Feb 14th and my second preference is Feb 21st.
あの有名なフグ一家の第一印象はどうでしたか？
What was your first impression of the famous blowfish family?

mnemonics.meaning: The most bad is the worst. At least all there is is up now, right?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 今日は最悪な一日だったよ。
Today was the worst day ever.
最悪、すいみん時間をけずって仕事をしなければならないですが、まぁなんとかなるでしょう。
The worst case scenario is that I just have to sleep less and work, but it'll be okay.
「昨夜、自動車を盗まれちゃったんだよ。」「げっ、最悪じゃん。」
"My car was stolen last night." "Oh, no! That’s the worst!"

mnemonics.meaning: Remember 一番目? This is just like that, but with three, making it the third thing or simply the third.
mnemonics.reading: Use your knowledge of the reading for 一番目 to remember the reading for this word as well.

sentences: この曲、ビートルズの中で三番目くらいにすき。
This is probably my third favorite Beatles's song.
コウイチなら左から三番目のトイレでハリーポッターを読んでるよ。
If you are looking for Koichi, he's reading Harry Potter on the third toilet from the left.
日本の有人島の多さは、インドネシア、フィリピンに次いで、世界で三番目だってこと、知ってた？
Did you know that Japan has the third highest number of inhabited islands in the world, after Indonesia and the Philippines?

mnemonics.meaning: The time period of time is a period of time of time. If anything, just notice how many times the word "time" is used and you'll remember this word means time. The meaning is a specific type of time, though. This is talking about a season or period of time, not the concept of time itself. That would be 時間 or something.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 時期が来るまで、見守ってやらないか？
Why don't we just wait and see until the time is right?
もうすぐハリケーンの時期ですね。
Hurricane season is just around the corner.
タケシは単によくあるフェーズにさしかかっているだけだよ。ほら、外国で暮らす人はたいてい、カルチャーショックの時期を経験するっていうじゃない？
It’s just a phase Takeshi is going through. Don’t they say people living in a foreign country usually experience a period of culture shock?

mnemonics.meaning: Throw this onto a number and you have yourself the number of times something has increased. For example, ３倍 means something increased "three fold."
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Omit the 〜 when writing out the answer, though. That just represents that there should be something before the kanji in this word when being used.

sentences: ワニカニのレビューの数が四倍になってしまった。
WaniKani's review count has quadrupled.
クリスマスの日ぐらい、きゅうりょうを十倍にしてくれたっていいじゃないか！
Why not just pay me ten times more than usual on Christmas day at least?
回転寿司の普及に伴い、日本におけるサーモンの消費量は輸入開始から三倍となった。
Since the introduction and subsequent spread of conveyer belt sushi shops, salmon consumption in Japan has tripled.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. This is an intransitive verb. That means it does not take a direct object. Something starts. No direct object here. That's why this verb means to start.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 始める.

sentences: そのえいがは何時から始まりますか。
What time does the movie start?
アメリカと中国のしれつなけいざいせんそうが始まりました。
A fierce economic war between America and China has begun.
銃声が、大食いパイコンテストの始まりの合図となります。
The sound of the rifle means the pie eating contest has started.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. This is an intransitive verb. That means it does not take a direct object. Something is transmitted. No direct object here. That's why this verb means to be transmitted.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 伝える.

sentences: トーフグに入社する前のビエトの様々な伝せつが社員に伝わっています。
Various legends of Viet before working for Tofugu have been told to the employees.
日本語が上手に話せなくても心で話せばきっと相手に伝わりますよ。
Even though you can't speak Japanese well, if you try to speak with your heart, people will understand.
忍者トーフグ組が夜に城へ忍び寄ったということが、コウイチ将軍に伝わった。
A message about how the Tofugu ninjas crept towards the castle during the night was transmitted to Shogun Koichi.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means climb so the verb vocab version would be to climb (or to ascend), if that's the kind of thing you're into.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. This has the same reading as 上る which you learned all that time ago in Level 1. If you can remember that, you can remember this one!

sentences: この長くてきゅうなさかを登るのはかなりキツイっすね。
Going up this long, steep slope is really tough, eh?
コウイチは、さるのようにスイスイと木に登り、いともかんたんにバナナを取っておりてきました。
Koichi climbed up the tree as fast as a monkey and came down with bananas without breaking a sweat.
一生の内、少なくとも一度は富士山に登ることが夢なんです。
A dream of mine is to climb Mt. Fuji at least once in my lifetime.

mnemonics.meaning: I bet you remember 集める which means "to collect." This is similar to that, except you're not doing the action of collecting, it's just happening. Instead of "to collect" it's to come together. You can remember this because a herd of Marus (the cat) will come together into one place if they sense a box there.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as 集める so if you know that word you'll know how to read this word as well.

sentences: クラウドファンディングで、こんなにたくさんのお金が集まりました。
This much money was gathered by crowdfunding.
社員旅行は、全社員が集まるいいき会になります。
The company retreat gives all the workers a chance to come together.
見て！あそこにヤンキーたちがたくさん集まってるよ。
Look! A group of miscreants are gathering over there!

mnemonics.meaning: You hopefully know that 要求 is a demand. When you make that a verb it becomes to demand something.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is just the vocab word 要求. It's also the regular on'yomi jukugo reading.

sentences: あんまりむ理なことを要求するなよ？
Don't demand too much from him, okay?
先方は、か格の点で妥協するようこちらに要求してきています。
They are demanding we compromise on the price.
彼にお金を要求されたから、ふざけるなって言ってやったんだけど、そしたらボコボコにされて、財布から無理やりお金を盗られちゃったよ。
When he demanded money from me I told him to kiss my ass. Then I was beaten up and he forcibly stole the money from my wallet.

mnemonics.meaning: You've seen how 落ちる means "to fall down." Now you're doing the action of "falling something down," aka you're dropping it. You can remember this because you kind of toss (とす) something and it drops to the ground, making this word mean to drop something.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 落ちる. So long as you know that word you can apply that reading over here, too.

sentences: 今朝、コウイチのデスクの下に生たまごを落としてしまいました。
This morning, I accidentally dropped a raw egg under Koichi's desk.
そんな信用を落とすようなことは今すぐ止めた方がいいよ。
You should immediately stop doing things that will make people lose faith in you.
今日、『男を落とす方法』っていう本を買ったんだけど、帰り道にどこかで落としちゃったみたいなんだよね。
Today I bought a book called 'How to Make a Man Fall In Love With You,' but I lost it somewhere on the way back home.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means extinguish so the verb vocab version is to extinguish something. You can also use this word to say to erase something, like data, and to turn something off, like the lights or the power.
