There are times when I wish I was surrounded by reporters again.
正かいの番号を全て丸で囲みなさい。
Circle the numbers on all of the correct answers.
日本は海に囲まれているんだから、塩はいつでも手に入ったんじゃないんですか？
Since Japan is surrounded by oceans, has salt always been available there?

mnemonics.meaning: You've hopefully seen 旅行 by this point. This is the verb version of that. Instead of "trip" it's to travel or to take a trip. These are fun to do. You should do them!
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as 旅行, but it also happens to use the reading you learned with the kanji anyways, so you should be able to read it.

sentences: アヤはかん国を旅行するだけでなく、日本にも旅行する予定です。
Not only is Aya traveling to South Korea, but she's also traveling to Japan.
旅行する前に美よう院に行ったんだけど、思ってたより短く切られちゃったんだよね。
I went to a hair salon before taking my trip, but it ended up shorter than I'd wanted.
マジ、終わってる。一緒に旅行をした後、彼が一週間も電話を折り返してこないの。きっと、私寝っ屁をこきまくってたんだわ。
Seriously, it’s already been a week since our trip together and he hasn’t called me back. I must have farted too many times while I was sleeping.

mnemonics.meaning: You've seen 起きる which is "to wake up." This is similar, except you are waking someone else up, which makes the meaning of this word to wake someone up. How do you differentiate between this and 起きる? Because of the す on the end. You wake someone up violently, wrenching their neck. They turn around and sue (す) you, making you wish you never woke them up. This can also mean to cause something. I guess if you wake someone up and they're not a morning person, you could cause something... like trouble.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as 起きる, so as long as you know that word you should be able to read this one. Of course, you can also imagine them yelling "OH!" when you shake them awake too, if that helps.

sentences: 折角起こしてあげたのに、意味なかったね。
I tried really hard to wake you up, but it didn't work.
赤ちゃんを起こしたくないので、インターホンは鳴らさないでください。
We don't want to wake our sleeping baby, so please don't buzz the intercom.
その人、仕事で問題を起こして、首になったんだよ。
That person caused a problem at work and got fired.
ビエットが100%正しいよ。今すぐコウイチ起こすべきだよ。
You are absolutely correct, Viet! We should definitely wake Koichi up right now!

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends in an う sound, you know this word is a verb. More specifically, this verb ends in まる, and most verbs with this ending are intransitive, meaning the action or change happens on its own. The kanji 温 means warm. So this verb means to get warm or to warm up. To help you distinguish this from 温める, you could think of a circle (まる) rolling down a hill all by itself, and getting warmer and warmer as it picks up speed.
mnemonics.reading: The kanji reading is the same as 温かい and 温める.

sentences: シャワーの水が温まるまで、ここで待ちます。
Until the shower water warms up, I'll wait here.
このヒーターだと、部屋が温まるのにかなり時間がかかる。
With this heater, it takes so much time for the room to get warm.
一キロ走って、体が温まってきた。
After running 1km, my body's getting warmed up.

mnemonics.meaning: If you have a hope and you turn it into a verb, you'd think it would be "to hope." But what is really behind a hope? It's a desire or wish, right? That's why this word means to wish or to desire.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your one wish that you have is to have a bigger nose (のぞ). Feel your nose, it's too small. You wish it was two or three inches longer. Of course, if it helps to imagine you want a smaller nose or a nose at all, that's fine too. Just make sure you wish you have something nose-related.

sentences: コウイチは自分の足のつめをなめたいと強く望んでいた。
Koichi had a strong desire to lick his toenails.
今はYoutubeで何でも望むものが見られていいよね。
These days it seems like you can watch anything you wish on YouTube.
髪切ったんだけど、逆に童顔に磨きがかかっちゃってさあ。年相応のお洒落な三十五歳の女性になることを望んでたのに。。。とほほ。
I got a haircut but it just made me look even more childish. I was hoping to look like a stylish 35-year-old woman. Boohoo.

mnemonics.meaning: You've seen that 旅行 is "trip." So who is someone who goes on trips? That is a tourist or traveler.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help if you know the reading of 旅行 already.

sentences: 最初、ぶあい想な旅行者だなぁと思ったんだけど、話をしてみると意外におも白い人だったのよね。
At first, I thought the traveler was unsociable, but when I tried talking to her, I discovered she was actually very interesting.
ふだんはこういった対おうはいたしませんが、旅行者でいらっしゃるということですので、今回は特別に対おうさせていただきます。
Normally we would not do this, but since you are a tourist, we'll comply with your request.
ねぇ、見て見て。あの旅行者の服装、全然年相応じゃないと思わない？
Hey, look, look. Don’t you think that tourist is wearing clothes that are completely unsuitable for her age?

mnemonics.meaning: The things you wear below your other clothes. That is your underwear. You do wear underwear, right?
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this one is all kun'yomi vocab reading, but you should know these by now. 着 uses the reading you learned with 着る, but this word employs that pesky rendaku, so remember that き becomes ぎ here.

sentences: 今日はコウイチは勝負下着をはいている。
Koichi is wearing special boxers today.
全ての下着の注文ひんを、き日通りに発送しないといけません。
We must ship all of the underwear orders on time.
どの下着が欲しい？植物柄？それともアニマル柄？好きなものを選んでいいよ。
Which underwear do you want? The plant or animal patterned ones? Pick whichever one you like.

mnemonics.meaning: When you meet for cooperation, you're coming together to help each other. One form of this is when people form unions. They're all cooperating and coming together to help each other and themselves.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 息子が折角コツコツためたお金は、協会ひの支はらいに消えてしまいました。
All the money my son worked so hard to slowly save up was used to pay his union membership fees.
明日は協会の集まりがあるので、六時に起こしてください。
I have to attend an organization meeting tomorrow, so please wake me up at six.
こんにちは。僕はコウイチといいます。オレゴン州ポートランド市のポートランド剣道協会で、イベントマネージャーをしています。
Hello. My name is Koichi and I am the events manager for the Portland Kendo Association here in Portland, Oregon.

mnemonics.meaning: Your bad mouth is saying bad things (as usual!). Everything that comes out of this bad mouth of yours is verbal abuse. One day someone's going to pop you in that bad mouth of yours.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the kun'yomi vocab readings for these two kanji, probably because this word is just two words put together into one (bad + mouth). Use your knowledge of the vocab words 悪い and 口 to learn the reading of this word. Okay, I lied. You can also do わるぐち if you want. Sorry to say such bad things before.

sentences: ビエトは意地悪なえみをうかべながらコウイチに大声で悪口を言い始めた。
Viet started shouting verbal abuse at Koichi with a malicious grin.
子どもの前では、おっとの悪口を言ったことがありません。
I've never bad mouthed my husband in front of my kids.
友達がみんなで私の悪口を言っているのを聞いちゃったんだよね。
I heard that all of my friends were saying bad things about me.

mnemonics.meaning: Things that are targeted as Japanese are more than just Japanese, they are very Japanese. This word may be hard to understand at first, but there are many things the Japanese consider to be Japanese-only. These theories range from reasonable to ridiculous, but either way, you'll see them described as 日本的.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help if you know how to read 日本 as well.

sentences: 日本的なくらしにあこがれています。
I yearn for a Japan-style life.
このアニメはとても日本的ですね。
This anime is very Japanese, yeah?
フグは、サーモンの中に「日本的な優しさ」を見出した。
Fugu found a very Japanese gentleness in Salmon.

mnemonics.meaning: The place you wait to join other people is a waiting room or a meeting place.
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings, but it's like the hiragana that normally sticks out is stuffed in. 待ち → 待, 合い → 合 and is pronounced the same too. I know it's confusing, but once you get it down you'll never forget!

sentences: 合図をしたら、待合でスクワットを始めてください。
Start squatting in the meeting place on my signal.
待合する場所がさむすぎて、ぼうこうえんになりました。
The waiting room was so cold that I got a bladder infection.
病院の待合でばったり久しぶりに友人に会って、昔話に花がさきました。
I ran into a friend from a long time ago in the waiting room of the hospital and we chatted about the old days.

mnemonics.meaning: What’s another word for a wolf man? A werewolf, obviously.
mnemonics.reading: You learned the reading for 狼 in both the kanji and the vocabulary word. The reading for 男 comes from the vocabulary 男. Put them together and you get おおかみおとこ. Awoooo.

sentences: また狼男が出たらしい。
I heard that another werewolf had appeared.
狼男をいじめるのはやめろ！
Stop picking on the werewolf!
今日は病気で仕事を休んで狼男の映画を見た。
I was sick today so I took time off work and watched a movie about a werewolf.

mnemonics.meaning: A hope is really a wish that you have inside of you (though it can still be a hope too).
mnemonics.reading: What's your one big wish? It's to have a different nose (のぞ). Alternatively, you could think "nose on me" for のぞみ.

sentences: あなたの望みは何ですか。
What are your desires?
時間をかけて努力すればするほど、望みをかなえることに近づくのよって母に教えられました。
My mom told me that the more time and effort you can put into it, the closer you will get to making your wish come true.
サーモンの望み通り、フグは彼女にプロポーズをした。
Just as Salmon had hoped, Fugu proposed to her.

mnemonics.meaning: When there's nothing but folds and angles, you have quite a mess. This word means with trouble because you certainly aren't traversing along a nice, flat piece of space-time, are you? Nah, it's all angled and folded. 折角 is one of those tricky Japanese words that doesn’t have one neat translation in English. The nuance is that something has come about with trouble, either through someone’s efforts, or a stroke of luck. It often implies regret, and is used in situations where you want to express that valuable opportunities, advice, or hard work were in vain for some reason. It’s also used to underline a rare chance that shouldn’t be missed.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Watch out for the せつ changing to せっ, though. Another thing you have to go through with trouble, I'm afraid.

sentences: 折角苦労して手に入れた宝石を、彼女は気に入ってくれなかった。
She didn't like the jewelry I went through so much trouble to get.
折角ですが、これ以上妥協することは出来かねます。
We appreciate the trouble you’ve gone to, but we're not able to compromise further on this matter.
おれの折角のちゅうこくをむだにするつもりなのか？
Are you going to throw away my valuable advice?
うーん。折角イメチェンするいい機会だし、後ろ髪を三十センチくらい切ってもらおうかな。
Hmm. It's a rare opportunity to get a makeover, so I think I'll have my hair cut about thirty centimeters at the back.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this vocabulary is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 私は狼に育てられました。
I was raised by wolves.
狼の赤ちゃんたちは元気にしています。
The baby wolves are doing well.
遠くから狼の鳴き声が聞こえる。
I can hear the sound of wolves in the distance.

mnemonics.meaning: Wood that is lumber is lumber wood.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: ひまだったら、木材を運ぶのを手伝ってくれない？
If you have nothing to do, can you help me carry some wood?
「木材」は、まだほとんど加工されていない原料としての木のことを指し、「材木」は、その木材を加工してすぐ使える状態に仕上げたものを指します。
"Mokuzai" refers to raw wood material that is not yet processed, and "zaimoku" refers to wood that is a finished product and can be used immediately.
二日なら時間を作れるよ。いつもの木材置き場で話さない？
I can make time on the second. Why don’t we meet up at the lumberyard and talk?

mnemonics.meaning: Don't confuse this with triceratops. Grass is closer together, and a little bushier, like this. It's also more random and squished down in parts. If you see a bush of lines like this, it's probably going to be grass.

There is a narwhal at the top of this slide. What's it doing? The narwhal is trying to increase its height. Picture a narwhal propping itself up on a slide. It's self-conscious of its height. It's trying to prove to all the other narwhals that it should be allowed to play in their narwhal games, even though it's not the same height as them.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means man.
You're locking the things that come out of your mouth in prison. The prison of paper and rules, that is. These words turn into well-formed paragraphs.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means past.

You're constructing a table. On the table is a drop of blood, which is your blood. This is from cutting yourself on the saw that you're using to make the table. Imagine yourself cutting yourself with the saw by accident. Ouch!
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means walk.

The thread you weave together to tell others about oneself is the account of your life. It's your very own narrative, tying everything you've been through together. Picture this account of your life, the thread of the narrative linking all of the different important points in your life together.
mnemonics.reading: You take this account and lock it with a special key (き). You only give this key to people you really trust, so they can read the account of your life and truly understand you. Picture the people in your life that you'd give this special key to. They'd get to read the account of your life, so make sure they're trustworthy before you hand that key over.

mnemonics.meaning: You run into someone's forehead with your car. The big forehead you hit is Kim Jong Un's. You know that now you're going to have the whole North Korean army coming after you. Imagine yourself running away from the North Korean army. You have to get to the border, the entire army is coming after you for hitting their dear leader!
mnemonics.reading: The army is after you. Each army soldier has a gun (ぐん) and they want to use these guns of theirs to shoot you dead! You killed their leader with a car and now they’re gonna get you back with a gun! Picture yourself running away from them as they shout and shoot at you. Hear the bullets wizzing past your head as you run away as fast as you can.

mnemonics.meaning: Grains look like they're on fire in autumn. They all turn red and orange and brown, the colors of fire. It's also fun to set grains on fire in Autumn, since it's getting colder. Picture all the grains in autumn. Picture all of the colors. The colors of fire.
mnemonics.reading: As the grains burn, and the season changes to autumn, imagine them yelling out in pain: "ACK (あき)!" Ah yes, the sound of the seasons changing to autumn. Ack! Ack! Ack!

mnemonics.meaning: You say to your leader, “Believe and trust in me, I’m responsible.” The leader doesn’t think you can handle your duties, so this is why you said this to him. You want him to believe and trust you. You can handle this task. Imagine yourself saying this to your leader. Say it out loud as you imagine saying it to a leader of some sort.
mnemonics.reading: To show you are serious as you say, “Believe and trust in me, I’m responsible,” you kneel down on each shin (しん). You have shin splints, so it hurts a bit, but you do it anyway to show how serious you are. Picture yourself pleading with your leader to trust and believe in you. Imagine the hurt of your shins with the shin splints as you kneel. It hurts a lot, but it proves how serious you are.

mnemonics.meaning: A mountain stone is probably going to be a really big stone. We're talking about a boulder here. This kanji makes a lot of sense. Just follow the logic.
mnemonics.reading: Although it doesn't share the kanji, this boulder shares the reading of the first part of the famous "Iwajima" (where a big battle in WWII took place). Think of a big boulder. Now think of it plopped into the ocean to make an island. What island is it? It's Iwajima (the historical spelling of Iwo Jima). Hopefully you know what / where Iwajima is. If not, do a quick history lesson to catch yourself up!

mnemonics.meaning: Your private leader is Buddha. You don't feel the need to tell everyone. But when you're alone you give your time to Buddha and let him lead your life. Imagine being in the privacy of your own home, your own room, and saying to yourself, "Yes Buddha, you're my leader." Or, if that irks you, don't. Your religion is your own private right, yo.
mnemonics.reading: Your private Buddha is a little different than other people's idea of him. Your Buddha is wearing boots (ぶつ). They're big and rubber, and they look fabulous on him. Picture Buddha wearing a giant pair of rubber boots. Yes, now this is fashion.

mnemonics.meaning: Your magic yoga brush lets you build what's in your mind's eye. You do the bridge pose, and in your mind you imagine your brush painting an actual bridge. When you open your eyes, there it is! A bridge has been built, leading straight to your front door.
mnemonics.reading: You build a bridge. Immediately after, someone is climbing up onto it. It's Ken (けん) the samurai. He waves at you and says, "Did you build this? The craftsmanship is amazing." It seems like Ken the samurai really appreciates your building skills.

mnemonics.meaning: If you see an animal among the flowers in a rice paddy, chances are it’s a cat. Cats love rice paddy flowers, almost as much as they love catnip. Picture this cat meowing and purring as it rubs up against all the flowers in the rice paddy field. Aww, it’s so cute!
mnemonics.reading: Wait a minute… This cat is pretty odd looking. You take a closer look, seeing it is missing its neck (ねこ). You go to pet it, but it's super sensitive about that area of its head, which is basically a face connected to a body... Try not to imagine this too hard. It is disturbing.

mnemonics.meaning: If the snow in winter was red instead of white, that’d be a strange change wouldn’t you say? White snow is normal, red would just be strange. Can you imagine what it would be like if the winter snow changed to the color of red? This strange change radical is a modified version of the red radical. Use that to remember it. It’s a strange change from the normal red radical.
mnemonics.reading: You know what else is a strange thing to change? The color of a hen (へん). Hens are already red, so we’d change them to another color, like purple. That would be a pretty strange color for a hen, right? Imagine if hens were purple, or even other strange colors. It would be an unexpected change. Imagine this army of rainbow colored hens strutting around and clucking up a storm.

mnemonics.meaning: The sun is out, the sky is blue, things have begun to clear up! Look into the blue sky and imagine the clouds parting as the weather clears up and you can see the sun. Gorgeous! The beauty is so great you have to squint.
mnemonics.reading: Now that it's starting to clear up you can't help but laugh. "Ha (は)! Ha ha ha!" you laugh up into the sky. The sun feels great on your face, making you feel lively! And that blue sky ain't too shabby either. Say the "ha ha ha" part out loud while you imagine the weather clearing up. It'll help you to remember the reading of this kanji.

mnemonics.meaning: You saw down a bamboo tree to construct and build a building. Bamboo trees are great for construction, so you saw down a bunch of bamboo trees to build this new building. Imagine yourself sawing down this bamboo tree. Feel the saw in your hands as you slide through the bamboo, wood chips flying everywhere.
mnemonics.reading: As you construct and build this building, you hear a strange cheeping noise. Suddenly a chick (ちく) pops out of one of the bamboo pieces you are building with. Then another, and another. You're surrounded by chicks! Imagine trying to construct the rest of this building covered in baby chicks. They're very cute, but this is dangerous! You have to build very carefully, so you don't accidentally hurt any of them.

mnemonics.meaning: When a mama stands with a man, it gives him courage. When all alone, though, the man has no courage. It helps when his mama is there to back him up. Imagine a man's mama standing there with him, saying "you can do it, boy" while giving him reassurance.
mnemonics.reading: A man needs courage to stand up to all the youths (ゆう) of the world. They are too numerous and difficult to understand. It's scary, but the man has courage thanks to his mom. Imagine a courageous man (and his reassuring mama) standing against the youths. They tell him things about modern technology and avocado toast, but thanks to his mama the man can keep his courage.

mnemonics.meaning: If you stand in front of a tsunami, you’re going to cry. That tsunami is going to hit you hard, and rip you right off the ground on which you stand. Who wouldn't cry? Imagine getting hit with the full force of a tsunami. It slams into you and crushes every bone in your body. It hurts so much you cry.
mnemonics.reading: Do you know the only way to stop yourself crying after a tsunami? That's right, nachos (な)! Nachos are the only proven way to cheer people up after being hit by a tsunami. Imagine stuffing yourself with nachos. The tears stop. You're feeling bruised and wet, but much better.

mnemonics.meaning: A creeper inside of a cape, who are they? They’re the director of a movie. They try to look all mysterious, but you know it’s just so people go see their movies and think they’re cool. Really they’re just a creep deep down. Picture the creepiest director you know. Wearing a cloak and cackling as he directs your favorite actors.
mnemonics.reading: The director is currently directing a movie about sheep (し). He keeps petting them and talking to them like they're humans. The creep director gets really into whatever his current project is. Picture him wearing a sheep costume with the cape over it, petting and whispering to his sheep cast.

mnemonics.meaning: This cage with treasure in it is actually a map of the district the treasure is in. Picture a big pirate map, and on it are a bunch of these markers for the districts where you can find the treasures you've been searching for.
mnemonics.reading: There is one district you're interested in, and that's the cookie (く) district. The treasure of the cookie district is cookies, which you want. And to be fair, even if you weren't a pirate, you'd probably want those cookies.

mnemonics.meaning: There are many flowers in the center of England. It may seem rainy and gray at first, but if you walk right to the center you'll see all the flowers that grow there in the center of the country. This kanji also means English, which is pretty similar to England. Just imagine all the people of England walking to the center, where the flowers are, and speaking English to them to help them grow. Picture yourself in the center of England, speaking English to all of the beautiful flowers.
mnemonics.reading: You keep walking to the very central center of England and see a giant acorn (えい) planted in the middle of the ground. This acorn is the source of all the flowers and life in England. Imagine walking around the giant English acorn. Touch its smooth surface with your hand.

mnemonics.meaning: The height radical and the height kanji are the same! That said, there's a secondary meaning to this kanji of ten feet. So, when you think of height, think of that height as being ten feet tall. If you paid attention in radicals school, you'll be able to learn this kanji meaning easily.
mnemonics.reading: When you think of height think of our huge farmhand friend, Jourm (じょう). He's a big guy, and he has a lot of height to him. In fact, he's ten feet tall. Jourm really is a big guy. Look up at him, and try to measure him, but ten feet is too high for you to reach.

mnemonics.meaning: The husband radical and the husband kanji are the same. How useful, unlike some husbands, I'd imagine.
mnemonics.reading: What do all husbands love? Food (ふう)! Can you hear your future husband? He’s saying, "Fooooood! FOOOOOD!” like some kind of food craving zombie.  Husbands love eating food. Who doesn’t though, really?

mnemonics.meaning: If you're anti-eat your meal will just sit in front of you, uneaten. Food is meant to be eaten! Stop trying to fast and take a bite. Look down at the huge meal in front of you. I guess there are plenty of reasons to be anti-eat right now, but you'll have to eat your food eventually.
mnemonics.reading: As you stare at the meal, Han (はん) Solo appears before you and takes a bite! This is what happens if you don't eat your food, someone else will eat it. Picture Han Solo slowly eating your whole meal! He's making constant eye contact with you, reaching down and shoving the entire meal into his mouth.

mnemonics.meaning: If you want to say how big a cross is, you have to measure it. You can't say the size of something without measuring it first. Imagine trying to use your hands to show the size of this cross, but the other person shakes their head and says, "Use your words!" Ugh, okay, you'll have to measure it then.
mnemonics.reading: You need to measure this cross but all you have is a cake (けい). Good enough! I'm sure all cakes are exactly the same size, so they're a reliable unit of measure. "This cross measures two cakes wide and three cakes long," you say.

mnemonics.meaning: Tsunamis in the past changed the methods and laws of today. Tsunamis used to come crashing into towns, just leveling them completely. Today we have new methods of building and protecting ourselves, and laws to keep them in place, so the past doesn't repeat itself.
mnemonics.reading: These methods and laws affected your own home (ほう) the most. Your home has strong walls and ceilings. You aren't allowed to leave the doors unlocked and open. These methods and laws are because of those past tsunamis and the damage they used to cause. Your home is safe thanks to them!

mnemonics.meaning: The sun has an excuse for disappearing at night. The sun gets really tired, same as anyone else – so when night rolls around the sun excuses itself and goes to sleep. It’s a valid excuse. Imagine you’re the sun, working all day. Of course you get tired. This is a good excuse to go to bed at night and get some rest. Feel how sore and hot and sweaty and exhausted you are after a hard day’s work of being the sun.
mnemonics.reading: Since you’re the sun, it’s pretty bright, so before you excuse yourself for the night, you’re wearing Ray-Ban (ばん) sunglasses. You keep these Ray-Ban sunglasses on all day to protect your eyes from being burned by yourself. You’re a pretty cool dude. Ray-Bans are cool. You even wear them at night you’re so awesome. Yeah.

mnemonics.meaning: The sun rises from the ground, and on top of it is a giant shrimp. It doesn't do anything except for every day right at noon, when it tells you the time. "Hey guyz, it's noon, mmk?" Really try to imagine this giant shrimp on the sun as a normal thing that happens, without fail, every day. The shrimp also tells the time right at noon, every day (so important you stress remembering that it's noon, not some other time). Maybe you could have him sing a "noon song" in your imagination as well.
mnemonics.reading: At noon, the shrimp also puts on its high heels (ひる) to get ready for the evening, where it wants to make sure it looks good for the other shrimp he/she meets later on. Right after the shrimp's announcement, imagine it struggling to put on heels, while sitting on the sun. This shrimp is almost bigger than the sun, actually, so all its struggles with its heels are easy to see.

mnemonics.meaning: To throw life out the window, use poison. To keep life safely inside the window, put that poison down.
mnemonics.reading: If anything's worse than poison it's doing Sudoku (どく) puzzles. Have you done Sudoku before? Imagine yourself completing these puzzles and concentrating really hard. They’re fun, but also challenging.

mnemonics.meaning: With the right key you can unlock the sun to yesterday, or a previous day. The sun is in charge of the day changes, so if you use a key to unlock it, you can control the flow of time and return to yesterday, or a previous day in the past. Behold the power of the sun. Imagine having the power to control time like this. Picture yourself unlocking the sun to go back in time. Feel the heat of the sun and the bright light in your eyes as you unlock the door to the past.
mnemonics.reading: Time traveling to a previous time, like yesterday, can be rough on the body. As such, you wear a small sack (さく) to hold your valuables while you’re ripped through the sands of time. The sack keeps your important stuff from getting lost. The sack holds your key to the sun as well. Imagine wearing this sack as you’re sucked through the vortex of time and space. Feel yourself spinning around as you hurtle back into yesterday.

mnemonics.meaning: A knife got stuck in Wolverine's forehead, and he has a towel wrapped around it to stop the bleeding, but he really needs to return home. Everything is fun and games until someone gets hurt. And in this case, very hurt. If something like this happens, it's always best to return home.
mnemonics.reading: Wolverine wants to return home, but he can't drive himself because there's a knife in his forehead and lots of blood, so he asks his friend the car elephant (かえ) to take him. Car elephant is just an elephant mutant that has a car on his back. Watch as Wolverine climbs up onto car elephant and returns home. Well, this party was a failure.

mnemonics.meaning: To construct a whole ceremony, you can’t just make it up on the spot. That is not a ceremony. A ceremony has a past. A ceremony is done a certain way because that’s the way it’s always been done. In short, to build a ceremony, you have to create a ritual first. Then, the ritual can be constructed into a bigger, more lavish ceremony. This kanji also means equation for some reason too. Just think of a ceremony that involves doing math and coming up with equations. How strange would that be? Pretend you're at this ceremony. Ritual and Ceremony kind of mean the same things, sort of. Don't worry too much if you mix them up a little - both will help you to remember the other. There's a reason this kanji is made up of the ceremony radical already!
mnemonics.reading: So, you’re at a ritual. Think of the most ridiculous ceremony you can think of. Give it a shot – I’ll let you come up with the ridiculousness this time (it’s good practice). When you think of your mnemonic, make sure to imagine it with a Sheikh (an Arabic leader). Have the sheikh do something ridiculous to help you to think of this sheikh (しき) and then remember this on’yomi. It’s good to practice making your own mnemonics up every once in a while. It’ll help you to add on to the mnemonics already here and make better ones more personal to yourself!

mnemonics.meaning: Take your yakuza knife and put it in a row with the others. You have a yakuza knife. There are a bunch there, all in a row, so you follow suit by putting yours in the row too.
mnemonics.reading: Should we put them in a row? Let's (れつ) put them in a row! Imagine a bunch of yakuza being enthusiastic about putting their knives in a row. They all say together "Ret's do it!"

mnemonics.meaning: If you visit a bar after a tsunami, you’ll be hanging out in shallow water. After a tsunami, you want to relax with a drink at the bar. Unfortunately, tsunamis cause floods, and the bar floor is immersed in shallow water. Picture yourself at this bar, sipping on a drink while you’re wading in this shallow water. Feel the shallow water getting your socks and shoes all wet. It’s uncomfortable and cold.
mnemonics.reading: What beer are you drinking at this bar while standing in shallow water? You’re drinking Asahi (あさ), the beer of the salaryman. Asahi is super dry, so it takes your attention away from the shallow water a bit. Picture yourself in the bar again sipping on this Asahi beer. Taste the beery beer taste of Asahi as you walk around the bar with your wet feet.

mnemonics.meaning: The simple radical and the simple kanji are the same! Simple is simple!
mnemonics.reading: One of the most simple things in the world is getting a tan (たん). All you have to do is stand outside long enough. It doesn't matter what skin type you have or what the weather is like. Eventually, if you stand out there long enough, you'll get a tan. Get a tan, it's simple, stupid! (Though it's terrible for you so uh... don't always take our advice, kay?)

mnemonics.meaning: This is anti dirt. The dirt is becoming not dirt as it goes on, forming a... slope! Really what is the air above a slope but anti dirt? This is some high level thinking, but I know you can do it. Picture a slope. Now picture an anti slope (like a negative image). It's all just dirt and anti dirt at the same time! Woah! Mind Freak!
mnemonics.reading: You need to know these kinds of things about slopes if you want to play soccer (さか). Soccer is pretty slope-intensive. You really have to know how to read their dirt and anti dirt to really get good. Picture a slope. Now picture yourself playing soccer on the slope. Now picture your anti self playing soccer on the anti slope.

mnemonics.meaning: When you see the spring sun you know it's finally the  spring season. The spring sun only comes out in spring, which is why you know for sure it's spring. Imagine a different looking sun that only comes out in spring but not the other seasons.
mnemonics.reading: When the spring season comes around, it makes you want to laugh: "HAR (はる) HAR HAR!" you yell. Go ahead and belt out a few "HAR HAR HARs" for spring. It's warming up, everything is coming to life, and you're happy. "HAR HAR HAR!"

mnemonics.meaning: The temple radical and the temple kanji are exactly the same! Brilliant.
mnemonics.reading: Someone died. You ask how this person died, the person who's getting buried by the temple. The priest/monk says it was in a tragic terror (てら) attack. That's too bad - feel sorry for the person and learn a little more about the terror attack, if it will help you to remember the reading of this kanji better.

mnemonics.meaning: What does the narrative origin have coming after it? Well, the way we've counted years for the past couple of millenia has a specific narrative at its origin, and everything that comes after it is AD, or anno Domini. You know which narrative we're talking about, right? (Just in case you don't: it's the narrative of Jesus's birth, which is the year that we start calling dates A.D.)
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 紀元後64年にローマで大火事が発生したのを知っていますか？
Did you know that in 64 A.D. there was a huge fire in Rome?
パピルスは紀元後10世紀ぐらいまで使われていた。
Papyrus was in use until about the 10th century A.D.
え、こないだ会った時より日本語めっちゃ上手になってない？紀元前と紀元後くらいちがうじゃん。
Oh, your Japanese so much better than last time we met, isn't it? It's like two different eras.

mnemonics.meaning: Drinking as much as you want is nice and all, but don't get sick. When you see this word, you know you're at an all you can drink place. Tip: Usually there's a time limit, so drink up!
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from the word 放題 (ほうだい) and 飲む (のむ). So long as you know those vocab words, you'll be able to read this one as well.

sentences: 食べ放題と飲み放題だったらどっちの方がおとくかな？
I wonder which one is a better deal, all you can eat or all you can drink?
「カナエ、ちょっと飲み会をき画してくれない？」「おっけー！どんなテーマの飲み会？」「うーんと、ビエトが日本で買ってきたコスプレコレクションのおひろ目会なんだけど。」「分かった。めっちゃ安い飲み放題のい酒屋でもいい？」

"Can you plan a drinking party, Kanae?" "Okay! What's the theme of the party?" "Well, it's for the presentation of Viet's cosplay collection that he bought in Japan." "Okay. Can we do it at a super cheap all-you-can-drink Izakaya?"
「じゃあ、あなたは昨夜飲み放題に行っていた訳ですね。他には何かしましたか？」「いや、まあそんなところだよ。」
"So, you went to an all you can drink place last night. Anything else?" "No, that’s about it."

mnemonics.meaning: When you eat as much as you want, you are getting an all you can eat deal.
mnemonics.reading: The reading consists of the readings of 食べる and 放題. If you know those you should be able to read this too.

sentences: 一しょに食べ放題に行ったのが、とおい昔のような気がするよ。
I feel like my memory of going to the all you can eat restaurant with you is growing distant.
日本で、ケーキ食べ放題のカフェに行ってみたんですが、思っていたよりもたくさん食べられました。
I went to an all-you-can-eat cake cafe in Japan and I was actually able to eat more than I'd expected.
よし、今がチャンスだ。さあ、焼き肉食べ放題へ行こう。
Ok, the coast is clear. Let’s go get all you can eat yakiniku.

mnemonics.meaning: A strange person is an eccentric. They are also an oddball.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: あの変人のクローゼット、見た？
Did you see what's in that weirdo's closet?
変人的なふるまいをしつづける世界記ろくにちょう戦したが、おしくも世界記ろくにはあと十分足りなかった。
I challenged myself to set a new world record for acting like an oddball, but I was ten minutes shy.
あなたの上司はちょっと変人ですが、すぐに馴染めると思いますよ。
Your boss is a little eccentric but I think you’re going to fit right in.

mnemonics.meaning: When it comes to building and constructing, the thing that puts them all together into one is architecture. If you don't have any architecture, who knows what the building will look like.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: あの会社が建築したビルは、たいしん基じゅんをみたしていません。
The building constructed by that company doesn't meetcurrent quake-resistance standards.
この建築ひ用の内わけを教えてもらえますか？
Can I see a breakdown of these construction costs, please?
多くの人が京都や奈良に残る日本の伝統建築に魅了されますが、私もその一人です。
Many people are fascinated by the traditional architecture found in places like Kyoto and Nara and I’m one of them.

mnemonics.meaning: The noun form of request (don't be tricked by the い on the end, it's not an adjective). So, request goes to a request.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same like お願いします. Hopefully you're able to read that by now so you're able to read this too.

sentences: お願い！手伝って！
Please! Help me!
「ちょっとお願いがあるんだけど……。」「もちろん。言ってみて。」
"Can you do me a favor...?" "Of course. Name it."
中小企業は小回りが利くから、こういう仕事をお願いしても平気だろう。
Smaller companies take on new challenges more rapidly, so they probably won't mind if we request a job like this.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: トーフグ軍のしんの指きかんはコウイチじゃなくてビエトだ。
The true commander of the Tofugu army is not Koichi, but Viet.
どうやっててき軍の追げきをかわせばいいんだ。
How could we evade the enemy troops' pursuit?
とりあえず軍の拠点に戻ってみましょう。
Let’s go back to the army base for now.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, あき.

sentences: 秋はわたしの一番好きなきせつです。
Fall is my absolute favorite season.
秋と言えば何を思いうかべますか。わたしはやっぱり食よくの秋ですね。
When you hear "fall" what do you associate it with? As you can probably imagine, I do think of "fall appetites."
はぁ？まだこの秋に一回ご飯食べに行っただけなの？あんた頭イッちゃってるんじゃないの？どう考えても彼氏って呼ぶのはおかしいでしょ。それは付き合ってるとは言えないと思うよ。

What? You’ve only gone out to dinner with him once so far this fall? Have you lost your mind? Don’t you think it’s strange to think about calling him your boyfriend? I don’t think you can say you’re dating him.

mnemonics.meaning: The director who is above you is your boss or superior.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: その上司のコートは、とても丈夫な生地で出来ていました。
That boss' coat was made of very durable material.
うちの上司は、日本のれきしに大変きょう味があるようです。
It seems that my superior is very interested in Japanese history.
シャークがあなたのこと、名ばかりの上司だと言ってましたよ。
Shark said you are the boss in name only.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, so you can read this one!

sentences: あの岩のところまでどっちが先に着けるか競争しよう！
Let's race and see which one of us can make it to that boulder first.
トーフグにはコウイチが岩みたいなかおをしている時は、話しかけないでそっとしておくという決まりがあります。
At Tofugu, there is a rule that people should leave Koichi alone when his face looks like a boulder.
コウイチは、夢の中で大きな岩が頭上に落ちてくるところで、目が覚めた。
Koichi woke up as a huge boulder fell toward him in a dream.

mnemonics.meaning: The England country is where England is. This word can refer to Britain, the United Kingdom and England! Note that イギリス is more common for "England" - but, since this is a kanji learning website you should learn this word.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: あの頑固な英国首相をせっとくするのはとても大変だったでしょう？
It was very tough work persuading the stubborn British prime minister, wasn't it?
毎年、大変な数の人たちが、ゴルフをしに英国をおとずれます。
A great number of people visit United Kingdom to golf every year.
英国と米国は敵対関係にある。
The UK has an antagonistic relationship with the US.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You go up to Buddha. You want to rub his head for good luck, because that's what you hear is good to do. Right before you touch him, he backs off and says, "Whoa! I'm hot, okay?" (ほとけ). You touch him and it burns your hand clean off.  Imagine saying "hot, okay?" in a strange accent to help you to remember.

sentences: ビエトはヤクザをやめて、仏の道に入ることを決意しました。
Viet has decided to leave the Yakuza group and follow the teachings of Buddha.
コウイチは、いつも仏のようにれいせいで、えんま大王のようにきびしい。
Koichi is always as cool as Buddha and as strict as Enma, the King of Hell.
「知らぬが仏」や「仏の顔も三度まで」など、仏に関する諺はいくつかありますね。
There are some proverbs related to Buddha like, "what you don’t know can’t hurt you," and, "the crushed worm will turn."

mnemonics.meaning: The buddha teachings are what you have to learn when you're studying Buddhism.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that 仏 gets changed to ぶっ for this one.

sentences: 仏教とヒンドゥー教のちがいを正かくにせつ明できますか？
Can you explain the differences between Buddhism and Hinduism accurately?
そんなに信心深い人間じゃないんですが、一おう神道と仏教を信こうしています。
I’m not a deeply religious person, but I practice both Shintoism and Buddhism.
仏教に伴って、お香は六世紀に日本に伝来しました。
Along with Buddhism, incense was brought to Japan in the 6th century.

mnemonics.meaning: When you measure and then calculate something, you are making a calculation. For example, you measure the length of a frog, then you calculate how many frogs you'd need to reach the moon. What is that? A calculation, of course.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: ビエトは今、飲み放題のパーティーにかかるひ用を計算しています。
Viet is calculating the cost of the all you can drink party now.
ああ見えて、コウイチは計算がものすごく速いんです。
Koichi is very quick at calculations, though he doesn't look it.
お母さん！こんなに沢山の計算をしたら、数学の天才になるかわりに逆に頭がおかしくなっちゃうよ。
Mom! If I do all of these calculations, instead of becoming a math genius, I’ll just lose my mind.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Meow!
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Neko neko neko! Kawaiiiii.

sentences: うちの猫は、暗算がとく意なんです。
Our cat is good at doing math in its head.
このクローゼットにあるりょうの四倍の猫の服が家にあります。
I have four times the amount of cat clothes in this closet at home.
助けてくれ！俺の飼い猫がスクラブルの ’M’のコマを飲み込んじゃったんだ！
You’ve got to help me! My cat swallowed an "M" Scrabble tile!

mnemonics.meaning: The account of a generation... this covers a whole generation, and considering how long Japanese people live, this account totals a whole century.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 「今って何世紀だっけ？」「二十一世紀だよ。」
"What century is it right now?" "It's the 21st century."
コウイチは少なくとも一世紀は生きたいと思っている。
Koichi wants to live at least a century.
あいにく、その日のスケジュールは少しきついですね。今世紀最大の日本語学習祭り関連の会議がいくつか入っているんですよ。
I’m afraid my schedule is a little tight that day. I have several meetings related to a Japanese learning festival, which will be the largest one this century.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. In fact, this kanji's on'yomi AND kun'yomi are しき, so you can never go wrong.

sentences: いったい式場はどこなんだ？
Where the heck is the ceremony being held?
開会式は九時にスタートする予定です。
The opening ceremony is scheduled for 9 a.m.
その儀式は退屈だったので、たくさん方程式を解いて時間を潰しました。
The ritual was boring, so I killed time by solving a bunch of equations.

mnemonics.meaning: Change and change equals even more change.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: コウイチは、天こうの変化にとてもびん感で、雨の日はよくへん頭痛をわずらっています。
Koichi is very sensitive about changes in the weather and he often gets migraines on rainy days.
十年前におとずれた時とくらべて、東京はずいぶんと変化しましたね。
Tokyo has changed a lot since I visited ten years ago.
うわ！すごいね。既に変化が現れているのが分かるよ。
Wow! This is amazing! I can see the change already.

mnemonics.meaning: If you say something is going to clear up, you're usually talking about the weather. That makes it clear weather!
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: 天気予ほうでは、明日も明後日も明々後日も晴れでしょうって言ってたよ。
The weather forecast said that it will be clear tomorrow, a day after tomorrow, and two days from now.
予ほうは「晴れ後くもり」だし、かさはいらないんじゃない？
The forecast says "clear weather, with clouds later on," so I don't think you need an umbrella.
折角の誕生日だし、晴れて良かったですね。
It’s a good thing it’s clear out on your birthday, eh?

mnemonics.meaning: You know how 器用 means "dextrous" and "skillful"? Well, this is when you're not those things. When you're not dextrous, you're clumsy and when you're not skillful you're unskillful.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just keep in mind that the reading of 不 changes from ふ to ぶ. If you're clumsy you'll get a lot of boo-boos (ぶ), get it?

sentences: 十代は、不器用な私にとって、とても大変な時期でした。
My teens were the hardest years for an awkward person like me.
不器用な助手が、不器用な手つきで、いつものようにクソ不味いコーヒーをいれてくれた。
My clumsy assistant made very disgusting coffee with his clumsy hands, as usual.
私の主人は堅苦しくて不器用ですが、正直者です。
My husband is strict and clumsy, but he’s an honest person.

mnemonics.meaning: When you believe in your self you have plenty of confidence (or self confidence). This is a good thing to have!
mnemonics.reading: How much 自信 do you have that you know how to read this word already? I bet you have some, at least! This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: コウイチは大変な自信家です。
Koichi is quite the self-confident person.
もっと自信を持った方がいいよ！
You should have more confidence in yourself.
ビエトは、誰よりもコウイチのことをよく知っているので、誰よりもうまくコウイチの顔を描ける自信があると言っていた。
Viet said he was sure he could draw Koichi’s face better than anyone else because he knew him better than anyone else.

mnemonics.meaning: That feeling of courage is courage.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: ワニカニユーザーは、コウイチのスピーチに勇気づけられました。
WaniKani users were encouraged by Koichi's speech.
他の人の意見に反対するにはふ通は勇気がいると思うけど、トーフグで働いている時はそんな心配はいらないよ。
It usually takes courage to oppose other people, but you don't have to worry about that when you work at Tofugu.
「フグ、私のお父さんは素晴らしい人だったのよ。いつも私に、流れに逆らって泳ぐには力と勇気が必要だ。浮かぶだけなら死んだ魚でもできるって言ってたわ。」「サーモン、それって、サミュエル・スマイルズの名言じゃなかったっけ。」

"Fugu, my dad was a great person. He always told me that it requires strength and courage to swim against the stream, while any dead fish can float with it." "Salmon, isn’t that a quote by Samuel Smiles?"

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji!

sentences: 私のおじは、中央区の区役所で働いています。
My uncle works at the ward office of Chuo-ku.
ここはちゅう車きん止区なので、車は止められませんよ。
You cannot park here because this is a no-parking district.
ここ最近、横浜の外国人居留区では、暴力行為がかつてないほど横行している。
Recently, the foreign quarter of Yokohama has suffered from an unprecedented level of violence.

mnemonics.meaning: The earth district isn't our solar system or something like that. We're talking about a specific portion of earth, and naming it as a district. So, what is this patch of earth? It's a district, area, or zone.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 来月から、この地区のたん当者が変わるので、あらかじめお知らせさせていただきます。
I would like to inform you in advance that the person in charge of this zone will change next month.
この地区には、りん時ふくしきゅう付金を受きゅうしている人が三十八人います。
There are thirty-eight people who receive provisional welfare benefits in this district.
コウイチは、近日中に地区検察局に自白内容を収めたビデオテープを送ることを計画しているようですよ。
It seems that Koichi is planning to give a videotaped confession to the district attorney’s office soon.

mnemonics.meaning: When you can't (not) believe in someone, it's because you distrust them. Maybe someone discredited them and now you mistrust everything they say.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: あの変人が不信の目でおれのことを見てくるんだよ。
That oddball is giving me a distrusting stare.
ワニカニユーザーのトーフグへの不信はつのるばかりだった。
WaniKani users' distrust of Tofugu just keeps getting stronger.
新しい日本語学習教材を部分的に公開することは、我々の会社が何か事実を隠蔽しようとしているとの不信を招くかもしれないじゃないですか？
Don’t you think that only partial release of the new Japanese learning material may feed suspicion that our company is covering up some facts?

mnemonics.meaning: Think about a part of the district. Separate them out in your mind (these parts). Each part is a division of the district. You can also take each division and create a classification of them. Go ahead and classify each one.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: この町では、校区が三つに区分されています。
In this town, the school district is divided into three divisions.
これは予算区分の問題なので、私にはどうしようもありません。
This is a problem of budget classification, so I have nothing to do with it.
私は、テロ行為と合法的な戦争を区分する必要は無いと思います。
I don’t think it’s necessary to distinguish terrorism from legitimate warfare.

mnemonics.meaning: English meeting and talking with each other. This is English Conversation. This is used a lot when talking about "speaking in English" for studying English and whatnot.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 私の兄は、英会話は上手だけど、計算は下手なんです。
My older brother is good at English conversations, but bad at calculations.
まさか。また英会話のテストに落ちちゃったよ。ショックすぎる。
Oh no, I can’t believe I failed another English conversation test. I’m so shocked.
英会話の試験でミスをしたことで動揺してしまい、さらに別のミスを誘発することになってしまいました。
I knew I made one mistake on the English conversation exam and I was so flustered that it ended up setting off another mistake.

mnemonics.meaning: This is seen on things like dictionaries. When you have an English and Japanese (style) dictionary, for example. You'll see it the other way around too, but this particular one is English Japanese.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 英和ほんやくの仕事をしています。
I work as an English-Japanese translator.
新しい英和対やくの本が出ました。
A new English Japanese parallel translation book came out.
おっと、キャメロンが泣きそうだ！ちょっとあの英和辞典を探して来て、キャメロンに渡してあげてくれない？
Uh-oh, Cameron's about to cry! Can you go find the English-Japanese dictionary and hand it to him?

mnemonics.meaning: The English language is the language you're reading right here and now. This is the English language. It is English.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 英語の発音は日本語の発音よりむずかしいと思う。
I think English pronunciation is more difficult than Japanese pronunciation.
もしこのレストランの店員も英語が話せるようだったら、今後わざわざあの店まで行かなくてすむようになるね。
If this restaurant's workers turn out to be able to speak English, we won't have to go all the way to the other one any more.
「僕たちは皆、英語と数学の授業が嫌いだ。」「ちょっと、一緒にしないでよ。私は両方共好きだし。」
"All of us hate our English and Math classes." "Hey, speak for yourself. I like both of them."

mnemonics.meaning: England writing is English Writing (or if you want to be fancy, English Composition).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: ここに日本語で文をかいて、その下に英文でやくを付けてください。
Please write the sentence in Japanese here and add its English translation below it.
わたしの母は高校の英語の先生になるために、大学で英文科をそつ業したそうです。
I heard that my mother graduated from the Department of English Compositions in college in order to become a high school English teacher.
ねぇ、忙しいところ悪いんだけどさ、この英文の翻訳にちょっと手こずっちゃってるんだよね。手伝ってもらえないかな？
Hey, sorry to bother you, but I am kind of stuck on these English sentence translations. Could you help me?

mnemonics.meaning: Every night is simply every night. What do you do every night?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 体を丈夫にするために、毎晩やく用酒を飲んでいます。
In order to improve my health, I drink medicinal alcohol every night.
私の夫は、毎晩五時に夕食を食べて、十時には寝ます。
Every night my husband eats dinner at 5 o’clock and goes to bed by 10 o’clock.
毎晩泣く子を抱きながら、子供の世話をするには大変な忍耐が必要だということを学びました。
While holding a crying baby every night, I learned that you need a lot of patience to take care of children.

mnemonics.meaning: What you believe in your heart, and not in your head, is your faith. This is something that doesn't follow logic, it's all heart belief, it's all faith.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note that しん changes to じん.

sentences: 私の母は仏教を信心しています。
My mother believes in Buddhism.
信心ぶって他人をひはんしてくるから、あの子のことあんまり好きじゃないんだよね。
I don't really like her because she sanctimoniously criticizes people.
彼の家族はとても信心深くてスピリチュアルなので、他のお酒を飲まずにスピリッツだけ飲みます。
His family is very religious and spiritual, so they don't drink any alcoholic drink other than spirits.

mnemonics.meaning: Poison inside the food is food poisoning. No fun when you get this :(
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 食中毒で会社を休んでしまい、大変申しわけありません。
I'm terribly sorry that I took a day off because of food poisoning.
ハーゲンダッツを食べて食中毒を乗りこえるというとても役立つ情ほうを教えてくれて、本当にありがとうございました。
Thank you so much for your helpful information on how to get over food poisoning from eating Häagen-Dazs.
フグが私に食中毒の危険性をレクチャーしてくれたんだけどさぁ、説明がすっごく分かりにくかったんだよね。
Fugu gave me a lecture about the risks of food poisoning, but his explanation was very hard to understand.

mnemonics.meaning: A large Buddha doesn't make sense if you don't know the context. There are giant statues of Buddha, and these are called Daibutsu, making this word translate to the Great Buddha or Giant Buddha Statue.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 昨日、ならの大仏をおとずれました。
I visited the Great Buddha at Nara yesterday.
大仏をすんげーしんけんに見つめてるあの男、だれ？
Who is that guy staring at the giant Buddha statue so seriously?
「彼女、大仏さんと付き合っているのよ。」「とても信じられないわね。だって、彼女の父親と言ってもいいくらい年上でしょ？」
"She’s dating Mr. Giant Buddha Statue." "You could have fooled me. He's old enough to be her father."

mnemonics.meaning: This word is made of now and night with the hiragana は at the end. The は here is pronounced as わ (the old pronunciation). When you say "now night!" you're really saying good evening.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just be aware that the は at the end is actually the particle は so it's pronounced like わ.

sentences: 今晩は。こんな所で何してるの？
Good evening. What are you doing in a place like this?
「あら、今晩は。」「今晩は。」「昨日の社長とのミーティング、どうだった？」「それが....てっきりしょう進するものだと信じてたんですが、首になりました。」
"Oh hey, good evening." "Good evening." "How was the meeting with the president yesterday?" "Well, I was certain I would be promoted, but I was fired instead."
今晩は、コウイチおじさん。今日は私とフグの赤ちゃんの面倒をみてくれて有難うございます。あ、ところで、電子レンジは使わなかったよね？ 母乳だから、電子レンジ使ったらいけないんだよ。
Good evening, Uncle Koichi. Thank you for taking care of our baby today. Hey, you didn’t microwave that, did you? Because it’s breast milk, you’re not supposed to do that.

mnemonics.meaning: The method of writing is how you write. You can have vocabulary words, but you have to be able to put them together using some kind of method. This method happens to be grammar.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ほう changes to ぽう.

sentences: 日本語の文法の本をさがしています。
I'm looking for a Japanese grammar book.
文法を学べば学ぶほど、文章をかくのが上手になりますよ。
The more grammar you learn, the better your writing will become.
私の上司、見た目はできる男なのに、いつも間違った文法を使うのが残念すぎるよ。
My boss looks like a smart person, so it’s too bad that he always makes grammar mistakes.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This word is usually used for clothing height and length.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is different from what you learned with the kanji. Remember the word 竹? It has the same reading as this. Just think of everyone measuring the heights of things with bamboo (たけ) poles with markers on them. Okay, this one is 5 bamboo poles high!

sentences: ユニクロで、七分丈のパンツを買いました。
I bought a pair of three-quarter-length pants at UNIQLO.
少し見ないうちに、ずいぶん丈がのびたな！
You've grown a lot taller since I saw you last!
話を変える訳じゃないんだけど、そのスカートはちょっと丈が長過ぎるんじゃないかしら？
Not to change the subject, but isn’t that skirt just a little too long for you?

mnemonics.meaning: If you ride a horse, that's horseback riding or, in some parts of the world, simply horse riding.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 乗, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Know who loves horseback riding? That's right, Jourm (じょう) the farmhand. It makes sense, with him being a farmhand and all.

sentences: 今朝、乗馬をしました。
This morning, I went horseback riding.
乗馬を体験してみたい。
I want to experience horseback riding.
最近は、乗馬クラブに通っています。
Recently, I've been attending a horse riding club.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Think about your husband even if you don't have one. What's his name? It's Otto (おっと), and he's always leaving you at home because he's working at the auto (おっと) shop.

sentences: 私の夫の歯は、とても丈夫です。
My husband has very healthy teeth.
私の夫は、大変すばらしい男性です。
My husband is such a wonderful man.
ほら、また始まった。あんたって本当にいつも自分の夫の不満ばかり言っているよね。
There you go again, always complaining about your husband.

mnemonics.meaning: A not law is something that's against the law. It's illegal or unlawful.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: ビエトが行っている不法のやみとり引のことを、トーフグの社員はだれも知らない。
None of the Tofugu workers know about the illegal black-market transactions that Viet does.
アメリカにはげん時てんで何人の不法たいざい者がいると思いますか？
How many illegal aliens do you think there are in the U.S. at the moment?
不法な捜査で得た証拠は法廷では使えませんよ。
We can’t use evidence obtained through an unlawful search at the court.

mnemonics.meaning: An action that takes place that could change the locale or even the world has got to be a big incident. You'll sometimes see this on the ends of "incident" names, like the "Manshuu Jihen" (満州事変), aka the "Manshuu Incident." You know that it isn't an unusual or strange incident (like 変事) because the "strange" kanji (変) doesn't come first with this word. Instead, it comes after and means "change" in this case.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 上海事変は何年に起こりましたか。
What year did Shanghai Incident occur?
事変という言葉を使った例文をさがしていたら、東京事変というバンドがあることを知りました。
When I was looking for an example sentence with the word incident, I came across a band called Tokyo Incident.
満州事変について説明をしてもらえますか？
Can you explain what the Manchurian Incident is?

mnemonics.meaning: When you get someone to transmit information, they're a type of intermediary, a go-between, if you will.
mnemonics.reading: When a vocab word is a single kanji with no okurigana, it takes the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this one yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember:  When the go-between gets back and is about to tell you everything the other group said, it takes him two takes (つて) to get it all right. The other group had a lot to say and he had trouble getting it all on the first take, but he totally nailed it on the second. Little side note: this word is actually more common in katakana, as in ツテ, or hiragana, as in つて. Still, you might see it in kanji too, and it's good if you can read it!

sentences: 母が亡くなったことを伝えたいんですが、おじさんにはれんらくする伝がないんです。
I want to tell my uncle that my mom passed away, but I don't have a way to get in touch with him.
伝をたよって、トーフグにしゅうしょくしました。
I got a job at Tofugu through my connections.
誰かの伝があるといいんだけど。
But I think some kind of intermediary would be good.

mnemonics.meaning: A child cat is an adorable kitten. D'awww!
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the vocab word 子 (こ) and the reading for cat (ねこ).

sentences: その子猫は、えだからえだを軽かいにとびうつりました。
The kitten jumped nimbly from branch to branch.
子猫が時計回りにクルクル歩き回っている動画をYoutubeにアップロードしました。
I uploaded a video to Youtube of a kitty walking clockwise, round and round.
私達、ちょうどこの子猫を見つけて、飼い主をさがしているんです。
We just found this kitten and we’re looking for the owner.

mnemonics.meaning: Yesterday's year was actually last year. Today must be New Years then!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この二十四時間スーパーは、昨年オープンしました。
This 24-hour supermarket was opened last year.
昨年は旅行でグアムに行きました。
I went on a trip to Guam last year.
昨年、医者から中性しぼうのあたいが高いと言われちゃったんですよ。
Last year, my doctor told me that I have a high level of triglycerides.

mnemonics.meaning: When things are put in a row they end up forming a line. This can be a line of people or a line of random stuff.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: 「列の最後びはここですか？」「いいえ、私は列の先頭です。」
"Is this the end of the line? " "No. I'm at the front of the line."
私のせきは、前から二列目でした。
My seat was in the second row.
ベーコンショップの前には長い列ができていた。
There was a long line in front of the bacon shop.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how you learned that 休み means "break?" When you take a break at noon it's your lunch break! Or, if you aren't hungry, it's a noon break instead.
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them already, so you should be able to read this too!

sentences: 大変だ！あと五分で昼休みだ。
Oh my! Lunch break is in five minutes.
今日の昼休みに食べたカツどんは、大変美味しかったです。
The katsudon I ate today during my lunch break was very delicious.
昼休みにゆかたに着がえるつもりです。
I'm gonna change into a yukata during the noon break.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. It also refers to cooked rice, because you gotta eat cooked rice with every meal, so it's basically synonymous with "meal" itself. This word has a slightly gruff feel to it so it's used mostly in informal situations.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're eating a meal... MMmm, delicious! What are you eating? Well, it's a Mesh (めし) net. Taste the mesh net. It tastes terrible. This is a bad meal. Feel it in your mouth. It's weird and meshy.

sentences: しまった！飯をたくのをわすれてた。
Oh no. I forgot to cook rice.
コウイチは三度の飯よりトーフグの仕事をするのが好きです。
Koichi would rather work for Tofugu than eat.
あそこの飯は本当に臭かったぜ。二度と塀の中には戻りたくねえな。
Those were some really stinky-smelling meals! I never want to go back to prison.

mnemonics.meaning: The ご just makes this word more polite and fancy. When it comes to food, it's nice to be those things. This has the same meaning as the kanji (meal) making it meal, but it also refers to cooked rice as well. So, "Come eat your ご飯" can be both "come eat your rice" and "come eat your meal." Really, since most Japanese meals come with rice, though, you can see how the overlap happens.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Now how about you "hand" me another bowl of rice?

sentences: 最近わたしたち、ご飯を食べるタイミングが合わなくてすれちがってばかりだよね。
Recently we haven't been able to get our meal timing right, have we?
しまった！ご飯こぼしちゃった。
Damn it! I just spilled my rice.
どうしてコウイチのデスクの引き出しには乾いたご飯の塊が入っているの？
Why is there a big ball of dried-up, cooked rice in Koichi's desk drawer?

mnemonics.meaning: The way method or the method way is the method or way. This is a good word for talking about how to do something. What's the 方法? Well, first you...
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: ビエトには、その方法はきかないっていうか、むしろぎゃくこうかですよ。
That method doesn't work on Viet. It actually works the other way around.
赤ちゃんをぐっすりベッドでねむらせる方法が知りたいです。
I want to know the way to make a baby sleep very well in a bed.
シャーロック・ホームズって、古びた犯罪調査方法を使っているよね？
Sherlock Holmes has an old method of investigating crimes, doesn’t he?

mnemonics.meaning: You've seen how the word 情け means pity, so adding ない to that turns it into an adjective meaning pitiable and miserable.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

sentences: 情けないですが、すぐに人を信じる性格なので、よくだまされるんです。
It's sad, but I have a very trusting nature, so I often get duped.
ツテでしゅうしょくするなんて、情けない。実力で勝負しろよ。
It's shameful to get a job using connections. You should compete using your merits alone.
日本の政治家には、本当に情けない奴が多い。
There really are a lot of deplorable Japanese politicians.

mnemonics.meaning: You've hopefully seen 映画 in level 13. A public building for movies (映画) is a movie theater.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 次にこの町にくる時には、この映画館が完成して町なみもずいぶん変わってるんだろうね。
When I come back to this town next time, I guess this movie theater will be completed and it will change the townscape quite a bit.
れん休も終わったし、あの映画館多分しばらくガラガラだろうね。
The long holiday is over now, so the movie theater will probably be very quiet for a while.
「今夜、映画館に行かない？」「そうできればいいんだけど、このレポートを仕上げなくちゃいけないんだ。」
"Would you like to go to the movie theater tonight?" "I wish I could but I have to finish this paper."

mnemonics.meaning: When you kill a person that's murder.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. So, if you know 人's reading as a vocab word and 殺す's reading, you should be able to read this word. Just note that ころし goes to ごろし due to rendaku.

sentences: 人殺しをしたら、刑務所に行かなければなりません。
If you commit murder, you must go to prison.
昨日、この近所で人殺しがあったそうです。
I heard there was a murder in this neighborhood yesterday.
計算ずくの人生なんてつまらないと思って好き勝手していたら、いつの間にか人殺しになってたんだ。
I thought it wouldn't be fun to lead a calculating life, so I'd just do whatever I please, but I ended up becoming a murderer before I knew it.

mnemonics.meaning: You've hopefully seen 殺人 (murder) from level 13. So, someone who does murder is what? A murderer.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: その殺人者は、とう走中に大変な失ぱいをおかしてしまった。
That killer made a terrible mistake while running away.
殺人者とうたがわれていましたが、ついにようぎが晴れました。
I'd been suspected of being the murderer, but I was finally cleared.
今の今まで、俺の友達の人生は信じられない苦難の連続でした。彼の人生は殺人者の子どもとして始まりました。
Up until now, my friend’s life has been an epic struggle. He began his life as the baby of a murderer.

mnemonics.meaning: The sea army are the branch of the military that has boats and does ocean/sea things. What's that? The navy.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 海軍にいた時、おれ的にはお前には十分すぎるぐらいやさしくしてたつもりなんだけどな。
By my standards, I was almost too nice to you when we were in the navy.
この海軍のしきたりでは、本当に悪かったなと思って反せいしている人は、自らすすんでトイレそうじをすることでせい意を見せることになっています。
As an institution of this navy, if someone is genuinely sorry about something, they have to volunteer to clean the toilet to show their good faith.
電話に出れなくてごめん。信じられないかもしれないけど、実は今海軍の船の上なんだよね。降りたら電話するね。
I’m sorry I couldn’t catch your call. Believe it or not, I’m actually on a navy ship right now. I’ll call you when I get off.

mnemonics.meaning: Something that's newly constructed is something that's newly built.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 新築の家でも買えば、気分が晴れるよ。
Buying a newly built house will cheer you up.
新築のマンション以外には住みたくありません。
I don't want to live anywhere other than a new apartment building.
悲しいことに夫に捨てられちゃいました。新築の一軒家を買ったばっかりなのに。話を聞いてほしいんだけど。
I’m sad. My husband left me even though we just bought a newly built house. I need someone to talk to.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading here is the same as the kanji reading!

sentences: 昨日の晩はフグの毒にあたって死ぬところでした。
Last night, I just about died on blowfish poison.
三日前の晩から毎晩コウイチがゆめに出てきてわたしにWanikaniを買わないと不こうになると耳打ちするんです。
Koichi has appeared in my dreams every night for the last three days, and he whispers in my ear that I will be unhappy if I don't purchase WaniKani.
「よお！今晩、飲みに行かないか？」「ごめん。今、禁酒中なんだよ。」
"Hey, why don’t we go for a drink tonight?" "Sorry, I’m staying sober now."

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this word is the same as the kanji it comes from, so you should be able to read it!

sentences: 今日の昼、あそこの定食屋でお昼一しょに食べようよ。
Why don't we eat lunch together at that diner during our lunch break today?
目ざまし時計が鳴らなくて、起きたらすでに昼だった。
My alarm didn't go off and it was already noon when I woke up.
今から一時間昼休憩を取るので、電話は取り次がないようにしてください。
I’m going to take a one hour lunch break, so please hold my calls.

mnemonics.meaning: What's the reason that something comes into being? Its origin, of course. Nothing can come into the world without a source, because it's always coming from somewhere.
mnemonics.reading: You didn't learn this reading for 由 so here's a mnemonic to help you: The best way to get close to the origin or source of something is to move into a yurt (ゆ). Yurts are easy to move around, so you can always get close to the source, wherever that may be.

sentences: お名前の由来は何ですか？
What is the origin of your name?
自然由来の材料を使っています。
We use ingredients from natural sources.
この単語は、ラテン語に由来しています。
This word comes from Latin.

mnemonics.meaning: If you take a ride as a guest (or a customer), that makes you a passenger.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You hopefully learned the on'yomi for 乗 with the word 乗馬, but here's a mnemonic to help you just in case: A passenger gets on at the next stop. Who is it? It's Jourm (じょう), the farmhand.

sentences: 乗客にとって安全であることが何よりも重要です。
The most important thing is that it's safe for passengers.
タクシードライバーとのおしゃべりを楽しみにしている乗客もいる。
Some passengers look forward to chatting with cab drivers.
ホームには女性の乗客が一人で待っていた。
A female passenger was waiting alone on the platform.

mnemonics.meaning: When you do a drawing of a measurement you want to do on the chalkboard, you're drawing up a plan for doing something. All things require some kind of measurement, so drawing that measurement up is your plan.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The reading for 画 is the secondary reading though (かく), so take note of that.

sentences: 夏休みに海に行こうと計画しています。
We are planning to go to the beach during summer vacation.
計画を立てるのは大好きなんですけど、計画したことを実行するのはきらいなんです。
I like to plan but I don't like to carry out what I've planned.
もし俺たちがエッフェル塔を盗むというなら、かなりしっかりした計画を練る必要がある。
If we’re going to steal the Eiffel Tower, we need to have a really good plan.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this word is the same as the kanji's reading.

sentences: 働きすぎは体に毒ですよ。
Working too much is harmful to your body.
ビエトのつくえの引き出しには、コウイチをいつでも暗殺できるように毒の矢が仕こんである。
Viet is hiding a poison arrow in his desk drawer so that he can assassinate Koichi any time.
フグはとても美味しく、食べる人の心を豊かにしてくれますが、一方で猛毒も持っています。
While puffer fish is very delicious and provides a deeply satisfying culinary experience, it also carries a deadly poison.

mnemonics.meaning: Poison Gas is a nasty thing. It is poison gas.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the kanji it comes from. The ガス is of course "gas."

sentences: 毒ガスは第一次世界大戦で使われ始めたらしいです。
I read that poison gas was first used in World War I.
午前十時からの毒ガスの使い方のレッスンを取っていたはずなんですが、もう一度かくにんしてもらえますか？
I'm sorry, but I'm pretty sure that I took the lesson on how to use the poisonous gas at 10:00 a.m. Can you recheck that, please?
「この野郎！また屁をこきやがったな！毒ガスのように臭いじゃねえか。」「すみません。もう二度とおならはしません。」「いいや、きっとまたこくさ。もう堪忍袋の緒が切れた。お前は首だ。」「そんな〜。」
"You bastard! You’ve farted again. It’s as stinky as poison gas!" "I’m sorry. I will never do it again." "No, I’m sure you will. That’s the last straw. You’re fired." "Oh no~!"

mnemonics.meaning: When poison is put inside of something, that is a poisoning.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 食中毒でかこきゅうになり、きゅうきゅう病院へはん送されました。
I hyperventilated from food poisoning and had to be taken to the emergency room.
ガス中毒にならないよう気を付けてくださいね。
Be careful not to get gas poisoning.
フグは麻薬中毒から逃れようとしてリハビリセンターに行ったが、結局また麻薬中毒になってしまった。
Fugu tried to rid himself of drug addiction and went to rehab, but eventually ended up relapsing.

mnemonics.meaning: When something has poison it is poisonous and toxic.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: ガラガラヘビって有毒なんですか？
Are rattle snakes venomous?
ダリンが道ばたに生えていた有毒キノコを間ちがって食べて、病院にはこばれてしまいました。
Darin ate a poisonous fungus growing on the side road by mistake and was sent to a hospital.
ビエトだけがコウイチのオナラが有毒ガスのような臭いがすることを知っている。
Only Viet knows that Koichi’s farts smell like toxic fumes.

mnemonics.meaning: You gotta believe it will return. What are you believing in returning? The reply. You made a request for something (come up with something you want really bad but have to ask for). Now you wait for the reply.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: やばい、返信するのわすれてた。ちょっと大変なことになってしまうかも。
Oh no, I forgot to reply. What have I gotten myself into?
き読になったのに、いつまでたっても返信が来ないんだよね。
It said "read," but I never got a reply.
お疲れ〜。返信したつもりだったんだけど、どうやら力尽きて、送信ボタンを押す前に寝てたみたい。ごめんね、許して〜。
How’s it going? I thought I sent a reply to you, but it seems that I was too tired and fell asleep before pressing the ’send’ button. Sorry. Forgive me.

mnemonics.meaning: A finger ring is the kind of ring you'd put on your finger. That's just simply a "ring" though, so you'll have to know what "ring" this is via context.
mnemonics.reading: The readings come from the individual vocab readings, 指 and 輪. In English we don't distinguish some other ring from a "finger ring" but in Japanese, you can think of this as two separate words coming together to form one word, which is why it uses the kun'yomi vocab readings like this. So, if you know the individual words, you should be able to figure out this word is read as ゆびわ.

sentences: 大事な指輪を失くしてしまい、気分が晴れません。
I lost my precious ring and I feel awful.
指輪が指から外れなくなってしまいました。
I can't get this ring off of my finger.
「ボーナスが出たら、ダイヤモンドの指輪を買ってやるよ。」「あなたはいつも口先ばかりでしょ。」
"When I get a bonus, I’ll buy you a diamond ring." "You always say that, but words are just words."

mnemonics.meaning: A ring of gum (ゴム) (which is what Japanese people call rubber quite often) is a ring of rubber. What is a ring of rubber that people use often? It's a rubber band.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 輪 is the kun'yomi vocab reading, which is わ, making this word わゴム.
