sentences: この輪ゴムはとても丈夫です。
This elastic band is very durable.
輪ゴムどろぼうのうたがいをかけられていたが、ついに晴れの身となりました。
They suspected I was the rubber band robber, but I've now been cleared of all charges.
わぁ！そのワンピマジで可愛い！カラフルな輪ゴムの絵がたくさんプリントしてあるんだね！そんなワンピ初めてみたよ。
Oh my God, I just totally love your dress! So many colorful rubber band pictures printed on it, eh? I’ve never seen a dress like this before.

mnemonics.meaning: A big change is a really serious thing. And people don't like change, either, making it a terrible event.  Also, in more recent history this has come to mean very as well.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 日本語を習とくするのは大変ですが、がんばってくださいね。
Acquiring Japanese is difficult, but do your best!
大変丈夫な子供が生まれました。
They had a very healthy child.
災害時は、電話回線もネット回線も混み合って、繋がりづらくなるので、ブログの更新が大変です。
When there's a disaster, the phone and Internet circuits are overloaded and it gets hard to connect to them, so it's difficult to upload new blog posts.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of shallow? It's shallow.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, making this あさい

sentences: この海は浅いから子どもも安心して泳げます。
This beach is shallow, so even kids can swim safely here.
考えの浅い人間にはなりたくありません。
I don't want to become a person with shallow thoughts.
酔っ払うと、眠りが浅くなっちゃって、早朝覚醒しちゃうんだよね。
Whenever I get drunk, I only get light sleep and wake up early in the morning.

mnemonics.meaning: If you're moving towards (に) simple, you're saying simply, merely, or only.
mnemonics.reading: If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: コウイチは単に大変な努力家なだけですよ。
It's simply because Koichi is a very hard worker.
「トーフグは、私にとっては単にお金をかせぐためのものではないんです。トーフグこそが私の人生なんです。」と、コウイチは言った。
Koichi said, "To me, Tofugu is not merely for earning money. It's my life."
剣道では、単に相手を倒すことだけではなく、自らの心を鍛えることも重要です。
In kendo, it’s important not simply to defeat your opponent but also to train your own mind.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading you learned with the kanji is the same as this one.

sentences: その寺なら、この坂を上ったところにありますよ。
That temple stands at the top of this hill.
ビエトは自転車でゆるやかな坂を下るのが好きです。
Viet likes going down gentle slopes on his bicycle.
スター選手であったフグを失ってから、トーフグ野球チームの調子は下り坂となってしまった。
The Tofugu baseball team has been on a downward slope since it lost its star player, Fugu.

mnemonics.meaning: An army person is someone in the army. What are those people called? They're soldiers.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: おきなわにはアメリカ軍のき地があるから、軍人さんがたくさんいます。
Because there are American military bases in Okinawa, there are a lot of soldiers.
その軍人の勇気ある行動が、多くの人の命をすくいました。
That soldier's brave acts saved a lot of lives.
昨日、上司に俺はリストラで首になるって言われちゃってさ。だから、今、軍人になることを真剣に考えてるんだ。
My boss told me yesterday that I am going to be fired, so now I’m seriously thinking about becoming a soldier.

mnemonics.meaning: A stubborn height is a shorter, stockier height. It makes a person especially solid, firm, and stout.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 土台はできるだけ頑丈にしておいた方がいいですよ。
You should make the foundation as firm as possible.
この車はとても頑丈にできています。
This car is solidly built.
眼鏡屋さんで、とても頑丈な眼鏡を作ってもらいました。
I had a really solid pair of glasses made by my optician.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Ah, the beauty of spring! Err... はる, I mean.

sentences: わたしは虫が苦手だから春はきらいです。
I don't like bugs, so I don't like spring.
「お前のチーム、春の大会ではどうだったの？」「へへ。大勝したっての！」
"How did your team do in the spring tournament?" "Hehe. Epic win."
春巻きという料理に「春」の字が使われているのは、春に芽が出る野菜を使って作る食べ物だかららしいですよ。
I heard the reason the character for "spring" is used for spring roll is because people used to make spring rolls with vegetables that sprout in spring.

mnemonics.meaning: You've seen 夏休み and 冬休み. If that isn't enough, you can see that this is a spring rest of some kind. That would be a spring break or spring vacation.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 春 is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. The 休み part is the same as the vocab word 休み, which hopefully you can read! If you know those readings, you can read this too.

sentences: 春休みキャンペーン期間中は、学生の入場料は一りつ千円です。
During the spring holiday promotion, admission is only 1,000 yen for students.
春休み中だったら、この時間たいは空いてます。
Any of these times during spring vacation would work for me.
そろそろ風邪治った？春休みに風邪引くなんて最悪だよね。もしまだ辛いなら、夜更かししちゃだめだよ。早く良くなってね。
Are you over your cold yet? It sucks having a cold during spring break, eh? If it’s still bad, don’t stay up late. Get well soon.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is more the "strange" meaning though, not the "change" one. As in, you 変な猫！.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. How strange! Or not.

sentences: はしらのかげに変な人がいると思ったらただのコウイチだった。
I thought there was a strange man behind the pole, but it was just Koichi.
同じ仕事をしているのに男性の方が女性よりきゅう料が高いなんてぜっ対に変だよ！
It's absolutely absurd that men get higher pay than women despite doing the same work!
変だなぁ。僕のメールボックスには、君が送ったと言っているメールがどこにも見当たらないよ。
That’s strange. I can’t find the email you say you sent me anywhere in my mailbox.

mnemonics.meaning: A strange action that takes place is something that shouldn't have happened (but it did). This is a strange incident. The difference between this and 事変 is that while 事変 can also be used to describe a strange incident, it also can be used to talk about another type of incident as well. For example, the "Manshuu Jihen" is the "Manshuu Incident." This word, 変事 is more just a strange or unusual incident.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: とつ然の変事で、今日のかぶ式市場は大変なことになっています。
Because of the sudden, strange incident, today's stock market is in a grave situation.
トーフグに何か変事が起きたんじゃないかと、全ワニカニユーザーが心配していたんですよ。
All WaniKani users were worried that some unusual incident had befallen Tofugu.
私は変事の前の不気味な静けさにいつもワクワクする。
I always get excited during that ominous silence that happens before an unusual incident.

mnemonics.meaning: With the height of my husband, he's very firm. Try to push him over. Impossible. He's so tall and sturdy due to his height.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

sentences: 私のつまは、あまり体が丈夫ではなく、よく病気になります。
My wife isn't very healthy and she gets sick often.
このいすはとても丈夫なので、すもう取りがすわってもこわれません。
This chair is so sturdy that even a sumo wrestler can sit down in it without it breaking.
彼が丈夫な男だってことは分かってるけど、暴飲暴食の習慣がちょっと心配なんだよね。
I know he’s a sturdy guy, but I’m a little worried about his excessive eating and drinking habits.

mnemonics.meaning: Something is making one thing the same as another inside a period of time. You'll see this word on computer-ish things a lot. This is syncing.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: iPhone同期中に電源が切れて軽くあせった。
When I was syncing my iPhone, it turned off and I was a little freaked out.
Dropbox、いつも写しん同期中にフリーズしてしまうのはなぜ。
I wonder why Dropbox always freezes while syncing photos.
たぶんもうすぐ反映されると思う。私のエバーノート今同期中だし。
It will probably show up soon. My Evernote is syncing right now.

mnemonics.meaning: Something with a beauty taste is something that is really tasty / good tasting / delicious. Mmmm, yum!
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this makes no sense at all. You'll have to learn it straight up, that is, unless you know the word おいしい already, which many people do as it's used in every other sentence in every Japanese variety show. If you don't know this word already, just think of yourself eating something delicious. It's so delicious it makes you mad, I have no idea why. You yell at the chef: "OI (おい). OI! WHY IS THIS SO DELICIOUS????"

sentences: コウイチとビエトは、オフィスに美味しいウィスキーをかくし持っている。
Koichi and Viet secretly keep some good-tasting whiskey in the office.
少しずつ、色んなしゅるいの美味しいものが食べたいんです。
I like trying little bits of many different tasty dishes.
最近、トーフグのオフィス内に、料理の美味しいパブがたくさん開店してるんだよね。
Recently, a lot of pubs with delicious food have been opening in the Tofugu office.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the kanji too! You must have been praying to the kanji Gods at the local お寺.

sentences: 昨夜、あのお寺で変死体が発見されたらしいよ。
Apparently, the body of someone who died accidentally was found at the temple last night.
子どものころ、寺のとなりに住んでいたので、仏教の勉強には大変都合が良かったんです。
I lived next to a temple when I was a child and it was really convenient for studying Buddhism.
日本の地元のお寺で誕生日会を開いたんだけど、すぐに追い出されちゃった。お寺ってロック・コンサートをやる場所じゃないってこと、知っておけばよかったんだけど。
I held a birthday party at one of the local temples in Japan. We got kicked out pretty quickly. I should have known that a temple wasn’t a good place to have a rock concert.

mnemonics.meaning: Previous from now are the times around now. They're these days, nowadays, or recently.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note that さく changes to さっ as many K-column sounds do in situations like this.

sentences: 昨今はあなたの様な大物にお目にかかれることはめったになくなりましたよ、コウイチさん。
Nowadays it is very rare to meet somebody big like you, Mr. Koichi.
昨今の流行りにあやかって、コウイチはオフィスでしば犬とチンド犬をかうことに決めました。
Owing to recent trends, Koichi decided to have a Shiba-inu and a Jindo in our office.
昨今は就職氷河期だと言われているが、会社を選ばなければどこかには就職できるはずである。
They say it's been a hard time for job seekers these days, but I'm sure you should be able to find a job if you're not picky about the company you work for.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means arrange, and the verb version also means to arrange or to put in order. This has to do with putting things in their rightful place, getting affairs in order, or even preparing equipment.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  Everything in your room has finally been put in order. Just as you finish, you hear a crash and turn to see your dog has jumped up onto your desk. "Toto no (ととの)!" you yell as he knocks everything over. Guess you have  to arrange  it all over again. Dammit Toto.

sentences: ビエトは、口ひげが三角になるように毎日整えています。
Viet arranges his mustache into a triangle every morning.
父のそうぎの手はずは、兄が全て整えてくれました。
My older brother put all the things in order regarding our father's funeral.
ホルモンバランスを整える方法をご紹介致します。
We’ll introduce you to methods for getting your hormone balance in order.

mnemonics.meaning: When you arrange something with reason you're arranging it. That's why this is to arrange.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 本だなを整理してくれたこと、大変感謝しています。
I really appreciate that you organized the bookshelf.
この書るいを全て整理するには、大変な時間と労力が必要である。
It takes a great deal of time and effort to arrange all of these documents.
ちょっと話を整理させてね。つまり、男の人が浮気をするのはいいけど、女の人がするのはだめってこと？それがあなたの言いたいこと？
So let me get this straight. It’s okay for men to cheat, but not for women. Is that what you’re trying to say?

mnemonics.meaning: You know that 好き is "like." Although 好き is kind of like a verb already, this is definitely a verb. It can be to be fond of or to like.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is a strange one, different from anything you've learned, kanji on'yomi or vocab kun'yomi. The reading is この, so think of this. What is it that you're particularly fond of? Getting a cone (この) with your ice cream (which you're also fond of, who isn't?). Think of all the different cones you can get: waffle cones, sugar cones, oreo cones, yum!

sentences: この日本酒は、大変酒好きだった私の父が生前に好んで飲んでいたものです。
This Japanese sake is what my heavy drinker of a father liked when he was alive.
コウイチは、黒ニンニクを好んで食べます。
Koichi likes eating black garlic.
コウイチさん、申し訳ありませんが、好むと好まざるとに関わらず、あなたの秘密は暴露されてしまうかもしれません。
I’m sorry, Mr. Koichi. Whether you like it or not, your secrets might get revealed.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means believe so the verb vocab version is to believe.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 信 is しん no matter what! See, if you believe, good things will happen. You should be able to read this.

sentences: 信じられないかもしれないが、実はビエトはスパイだったんだよ。
Believe it or not, Viet turned out to be a spy.
自分が目にしたもの以外は信じない主ぎなんです。
I'm the type of person who only trusts what they can actually see.
自分がもはやサンタクロースを信じていないということに、最近イライラしている...と思うんだよね。
I guess I've been irritated lately by the fact that I no longer believe in Santa Claus.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means build so the verb vocab version is to build.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Think about what happens when you build something. What are you doing? You're standing it up. How do you say "to stand" in Japanese? たてる. That's the reading of this word as well. If you think about it they're similar!

sentences: この男は、とても丈夫な家を建てることで有名です。
This man is well known for building very sturdy houses.
その王は、山の上に信じられないほど美しいおしろを建てました。
The king built an unbelievably beautiful castle on top of the mountain.
我が社は、外国の子どもたちに学校を建ててあげるために貯金をしています。
Our company is saving money to build a school for children in another country.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji is change, and this verb is to change something. If you change one thing for another thing, you are going to change it, after all. This word refers to changing one thing for a similar thing.
mnemonics.reading: I don't like this car. I would like to change it for another car (か).

sentences: 大人になると、考え方を変えることはむずかしいです。
When you become an adult, it's difficult to change your way of thinking.
あっ、フグのくちびるの形は変えないでください。それはコウイチの好物のタラコをモチーフにしているんです。変えたらコウイチが悲しみます。
Oh, please do not change the shape of Fugu's lips. They were inspired by Koichi's favorite food, cod roe. If you change them, Koichi will be sad.
眉毛の形を変えると、まるで別人のようだね。
When you change the shape of your eyebrows, you look like a different person.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means clear up, so the verb vocab version is to clear up. It also means to become sunny as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading you learned with the kanji is the one you use here. One of those words where the kun'yomi's going to be more useful.

sentences: 今は雨がふってますけど、二時までには晴れると思いますよ。
It's raining right now, but I think it will clear up by two.
昨日はよく晴れて良かったですね。
It was good that it ended up being very sunny yesterday.
ようやくフグと結婚することになったので、是非式に来てほしいなと思っています。詳細を同封した招待状を後ほどお送りしますね。パーティーは野外の予定なので、当日晴れるといいんだけどな。
I’m finally getting married to Fugu and I want you to be at our wedding. I’ll send you an invitation with all the details later. The reception will be outside, so I hope it’s sunny that day.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means cry so the verb vocab version is to cry.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. If you remember the kanji reading you'll have no problem with this word.

sentences: ヤバイ。うれしすぎて、泣きそう。
Aww. I'm so happy I'm about to burst into tears!!
情けないことに、晴れのぶ台で泣いてしまった。
It's shameful that I cried onstage in public.
減給になっちゃって泣いてます。もっと給料のいい会社に移りたいよ。
I’m crying because my salary was cut. I want to transfer to a higher paying job.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. You already learned the verbs 放す and 放れる but this one is a little different. This is a specific kind of releasing. It means to fire an arrow, or to hit a baseball. It even works when you're releasing a fart. Yes, it means to break wind too. What a great word!
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

sentences: コウイチは、するどく変化するサーブを放つバレーボール選手として知られている。
Koichi is known for being a volleyball player that can serve a very sharp curveball.
その選手は、ホームランを放ったしゅん間、くさいオナラも放った。
That player let out a stinky fart as soon as he hit a home run.
この鳥をいつか籠から放つつもりですか。
When are you thinking of letting this bird out of the cage?

mnemonics.meaning: Hopefully you've seen 暗記 before now. It means "memorization." So, turn that into a verb and you have to memorize.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 暗記. It also is the reading you learned with the kanji too.

sentences: クリステンはセーラームーンのテーマ曲の歌しを暗記している。
Kristen knows the lyrics of the Sailor Moon's theme song by heart.
明日までに、台本に書いてあるセリフを一つ残らず暗記しなければいけません。
I have to memorize every single line in the script by tomorrow.
文を丸ごと暗記する方が、単語だけを暗記するより効率がいい。
Memorizing sentences is more efficient than memorizing words by themselves.

mnemonics.meaning: You've hopefully seen 練習, which means "practice." So, if you make it into a verb, you have to practice.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from the kanji as well as from the vocab word 練習. You should be able to read this!

sentences: 昨日、肉って言葉の発音を六時間も練習したんだぜ。
I practiced pronouncing the word "meat" for six hours yesterday.
「おんをあだで返すような子に育てたおぼえはないよ！」というしばいのセリフを言うのを練習しています。
I'm practicing the line in the play that goes, "I didn't raise you to be such an ungrateful child!"
「俺達、惨敗しちまったな。」「ああ、惨敗しちまった。もっとたくさん練習しないとな。」
"Dude, we were absolutely crushed." "Yeah, it was a complete failure. I guess we need more practice."

mnemonics.meaning: You know that 映る is "to be reflected." Now you're doing the reflecting, which is really projecting (light). That's why this word is to project.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as 映る. So long as you know the reading of 映る you should be able to read this one too.

sentences: スクリーンにスライドを映し始めてもらえますか？
Can you start projecting slides onto the screen for me?
この白いかべをスクリーン代わりにして映画を映すのはどうでしょう。
Why don't we use this white wall as a screen to project the movie?
ビエトだけが、コウイチが鏡に全身を映すのが好きだということを知っている。
Only Viet knows that Koichi really likes seeing himself reflected full-length in the mirror.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means return home so the verb vocab version is to return home, to return, or to go home.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. You can return home happily, knowing how to read this word!  This word has a pair verb though, so you'll want to remember the る ending. Just imagine how rude (る) it is when someone goes home without saying goodbye. The nerve!

sentences: カナエちゃんは、日本から帰ってきて、オフィスの人におみやげを配りました。
Kanae distributed souvenirs to her colleagues after she had come back from Japan.
「好む」という単語をか去形にしなさい、という問題の答えが分からないまま、家に帰りました。
I couldn't figure out the answer to the question asking to put the word "to like" in the past tense, so I just went home.
「お腹が空いたし足が痛いよ」と、ホビット庄に帰るちょっと前にビルボーは言った。
"I’m hungry and my legs are sore," Bilbo said, just before turning to return home to the Shire.

meanings: to show someone what one can do

mnemonics.meaning: When you see someone doubting you and return something successful instead, that is to show someone what one can do or more simply to show someone. In other words, you show someone who doubted you or treated you unfairly what you’re really capable of. There are a couple of other meanings, too. It can mean to look back over something, like the answers to your kanji test you want to double check, and sometimes to return someone’s stare. You can see how all of these meanings relate to the kanji, right?
mnemonics.reading: The readings are from the words 見 and 返す put together.

sentences: トーフグの社長になって、コウイチを見返してやるぞ！
I will be the Tofugu president and show Koichi, who looked down on me, what I can do.
子猫にイワシをあげたら、「本当にいいの？」って感じの顔でマジマジと見返してきたのがマジかわいかった。
When I gave the kitten some sardines, she looked back at me with a face that was like, "Is this really for me?!" and it was super cute.
答案は提出する前に見返したほうがいい。
You should look back over your test before you submit it.

mnemonics.meaning: When you join all your measurements together you have yourself a total.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ビエトのさぎにひっかかったひがい者の合計は、百人になった。
The total number of the victims who were fished by Viet's scam came to one hundred.
合計金がくを出してもらっていいですか？
Can you come up with the total for me, please?
何度も足し算をしたんですが、その度に合計が違ったんですよね。私、馬鹿なんでしょうか？
I added the numbers over and over again and got a different sum each time. Am I stupid?

mnemonics.meaning: If you believe in the numbers, there will be no traffic because the traffic light will be functioning properly. Traffic lights are based all off of traffic data and numbers. You just have to believe and hope it all works out in terms of these traffic lights.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 赤信号で止まって、青信号でわたるのよ。
You stop at a red light and cross the street at a green light, okay?
あぶないから、信号をむししてはいけませんよ。
It's dangerous to ignore traffic lights, so don't do that okay?
いいか、よく聞けよ。六つ目の信号で左折した後、八つ目の角まで歩いて右折したら、そこで会った人に向かってお尻を振るんだ。それが秘密のサインだからな。そしたら、奴はお前を俺たちのアジトまで連れて行ってくれるさ。

Listen carefully. Turn left at the sixth traffic light, walk another eight blocks, turn right and shake your butt toward someone you will meet there. That’s the secret sign, okay? Then, he will take you to our hideout.

mnemonics.meaning: Your task is to believe. In order to do that, you have to have plenty of trust in what you believe in... not to mention confidence.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: トーフグチームは、コウイチの言うことを全めん的に信用しています。
The Tofugu team completely trusts what Koichi says.
コウイチの不しょう事が、トーフグの信用をきずつけてしまった。
Koichi's scandal has injured Tofugu's credit.
私は、掃除や料理、マッサージや寝る前の歌なんかで、妻から信用点をつけられていると思っていたが、なんと逆に離婚されてしまったよ。
I thought I would score some points with my wife if I cleaned the house, made dinner, gave her a massage, and sung her to sleep, but instead she divorced me.

mnemonics.meaning: A strange death is one that doesn't seem right. It's an unnatural death, and probably an accidental death (ie wasn't caused by natural causes).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: けいさつは、コウイチの変死についてちょうさしています。
The police are investigating Koichi's unnatural death.
「なんかパニクってるけど、どうしたの？」「コウイチは変死して、トーフグがとうさんするって聞いたんだよ。最悪だよ。」
"You look upset. Is everything alright?" "I just heard that Koichi died an accidental death and Tofugu went bankrupt. It’s a nightmare."
コウイチが謎の変死を遂げたというニュースは、全国民を震撼させた。
The news that Koichi met a mysterious and unnatural death shocked the nation.

mnemonics.meaning: A thing that gives you time measurements is a watch or clock. Most people have these in their phones instead of on their wrists now.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this is pretty weird. 計 is all nice and normal, but 時 is と for some reason. It probably is coming from the vocab word 時 (とき), is my guess. But even if it is, it's shortened, making it a step more complicated. Maybe it's just better to imagine that your watch is a walky talky (とけい) and run with that?

sentences: コウイチはビエトにもらった時計を船から落としてしまいました。
Koichi dropped the clock Viet had given him from the ship.
時計台の下で、三時に待ち合わせね！
We're gonna meet at the clock tower at 3 p.m., okay?
ねぇ、あなたの時計に唾が着いてない？
Hey, isn’t that spit on your watch?

mnemonics.meaning: The simple bits of language are the individual words. If you think about it, this is true. First of all, there are a ton of them. Second, they're tiny. They're just little bits of language and the "word" for these little bits is word. So what’s the difference between this and 言葉? Well, 言葉 can cover any meaningful set of words – anything from words, sentences and paragraphs, to whole texts and even languages. 単語, on the other hand, is a subset of 言葉 that specifically refers to single, distinct words.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 日本語の単語の単語ちょうを作りました。
I made a notebook for Japanese vocabulary.
単語の意味が分からない時は、じしょを引きます。
When I don't know the meaning of a word, I look it up in my dictionary.
日本語の単語ゲーム作ったんだけど、やってみない？
I created a Japanese word game. Do you want to try?

mnemonics.meaning: The yesterday day is yesterday. What a blast from the past!
mnemonics.reading: Oof. The reading for this word makes no sense. You'll have to forget everything you've learned about the readings of the kanji and just go straight up mnemonic for the word on its own. Okay. Think about what you did yesterday, all day. You played keno (きのう), gambling away your grandmother's money. Yesterday was the worst day ever because you lost everything playing Keno. Today is different, not like yesterday, right?

sentences: 昨日の夜は、よくねむれた？
Did you sleep well last night?
昨日はアメリカとカナダで労働者の日でした。
It was Labor Day in the U.S. and Canada yesterday.
昨日は、大学の課題で、沢山の叙事詩を読まなくてはいけませんでした。
We had to read many epic poems yesterday for a university assignment.
